Row.txt_code: yo2

This album and Reasonable Dought are always debatable bests for Jay-Z fanatics, but The Blueprint could easily be his best work. Released in 2001, this album came at a time that no one really expected. Jay was already at the top of the rap game, and nobody really expected him to get much better at what he did. But as this album shows, Jay is an unpredictable rap artist, and indeed he took a few turns that I didn't expect him to ...
inactivate

As you guide the relaxation and painting process, you could focus on words that bring hope.  For example strength, wisdom, courage, joy.  The participants could imagine breathing these things in, feeling them fill their bodies, and express them in shapes and colors in their paintings.

As you guide the relaxation and painting process, you could imagine breathing in self-care, listening deeply for what we need to do to take care of ourselves, and noticing whatever shapes and colors come to mind as we think of taking care of ourselves.

With this variation, you could encourage each participant to notice a worry or challenge that she wants guidance or help with and put it into shapes and colors. Then through the process
of painting that shape in consecutive paintings, she can see what emerges and how it transforms, just in shapes and colors, exploring how that challenge can be resolved or transformed.

Have a jar of inspirational quotes so each person can pick one without looking, see what they quote inspires in her, and then paint shapes and colors inspired by the quote.  (see enclosed list to copy and cut up for your jar).
Or:
Hand out the entire list of inspirational quotes to each participant so she can read them, choose her favorite ones, and then create paintings expressing these quotes in shapes and
colors.

Row.str_name: Binding into a Painted Prayers Book
Row.txt_code: The paintings and words from any of these variations could be bound together into little books each person can use as a source of inspiration and strength. It could be her Personal Reminders Book, her Personal Rulebook, her Personal Inspiration Book. Each woman could come up with her own title and purpose for how she wants to use her book.

You can decorate your box with Super Sculpey instead of collage.  To do this, roll out a piece of Super Sculpey to create a thin Super Sculpey "tortilla."  Put the cover of your match-box in the middle of this "tortilla" and cover the outside of it with this.  Cut excess on side with an Exacto knife - DON'T FOLD THE CLAY OVER THE EDGE INTO THE INSIDE OF THE BOX BECAUSE YOU WON'T BE ABLE TO OPEN AND CLOSE THE BOX.  Make a second "tortilla" for the other side of the cover.  Use Super Sculpey to create a 3-dimentional design on top of the box.  Make flowers or  abstract shapes and then place them on top of the Super Sculpey "tortilla"  layer that is in place.  Be sure to press them in—don't just place them on top.  Once finished, bake it in the oven like usual.  The Super Sculpey protects the box from burning, but keep checking the oven.  If your box has a lot of pieces sticking out of it, paint a couple of thin layers of Gesso to make the Super Sculpey a little tougher so it won't break apart while you paint it (or afterwards).  Now paint the Super Sculpey.  Once dried (you might have to wait a while), cover the whole work with a layer of Mod-Podge to give it shine and to protect the paint.
Just write with pens and markers on the paper feather pattern instead of using the foil and plastic wrap.

In this variation, everyone works on creating one large prayer ornament.  The participants each put their prayer onto a small colored circle.  Then they attach their small circles to the larger one using a hole punch and ribbons.  It ends up looking sort of like an advent calendar where you can open up individual circles.

In this variation, everyone makes individual ornaments that they can use to decorate a tree or the walls of the shelter.  I recommend making the ornaments card-like so they can open up.  Decorate the front as an art gift to God and write the prayer inside.  Use a hole punch and ribbon to hang each one.

If the idea of looking into the past seems too difficult, you could just call the workshop “Growing, Step by Step” and have each person use their three squares to illustrate a way they wish to grow, step by step.

Materials:
Cray-Pas (or crayons, markers, pastels, etc.) and paper

Project:
Draw an image of how it was to sleep while you were in the abusive relationship, and how you want sleep to be, now, when you are free of the abusive relationship.  Put words into the drawings as needed.

Materials:
Smooth rocks (can be purchased at garden and home supply places), paint pens (any opaque pens that can write on rocks)





Sleep Rock



Project:
Select a rock to be your special sleep rock.  Hold it and let your eyes close.  As you rest with your rock, notice what thoughts your rock holds for you.  What thoughts about sleep, about resting, about you?  What words come to mind?  When you are ready, write these words on your rock.

Materials:
Strong paper plates, scissors, string, hole-punches, beads, feathers, markers

Project:





Dream-Catcher



Dream-Catchers come from the traditions of some Indigenous American tribes.  They are based on the belief that dreams are messages sent to us from sacred beings during our sleep.  The Dream-Catchers, web-like hoops are placed by our heads during sleep so that they can catch the bad dreams (messages) and permit the good ones to pass through and reach our minds during sleep.  Then, when the rays of the sun come up in the morning the bad dreams are burnt away and therefore we are only left with the good ones.  (A simplified way of creating Dream-Catchers is written in the AWBW Children’s Windows Manual.  If you need a copy of the workshop, let us know.)

Materials:
Colored construction paper, scissors, markers, Cray-Pas, hole puncher, ribbons







Nap Permission Slip



Project:
Sometimes we are told that taking naps is lazy or bad.  The truth is that naps can be a very important part of recovering from stresses and gaining strength and clarity.  Write for yourself permission slips to nap.  Decorate them with ribbons, designs, whatever will help remind you that naps are a very good thing.  (You might want to check out a wonderful book by Sark: Change Your Life Without Getting Out of Bed:  The Ultimate Nap Book.)

Materials:
Flat, rectangular make-up sponges, ribbons, scissors, acrylic paints, brushes, water





Nap-Goggles, ready for painting.


Project:





Poking ribbon through the hole.





Pulling ribbon through, after poking.



Sometimes it is nice to have something soft and comforting pressing gently on your eyes, blocking out the light, and reminding you it’s okay to sleep.  (This can be especially important for day-time naps!)  To tie your goggles together, gently poke a hole in the sponge with the tip of scissors.  Then poke the ribbon through with the scissor tip to thread.  (Poke gently!  The sponges can rip.)  Tie your goggles together in the center to fit over your nose.  Then tie the outside ribbon to fit around your head. When you are ready, paint on the outside of them whatever images remind you of the deep, delicious rest that you deserve everyday.




Tupelo puts her Nap-Goggles to use.

Materials:
Supplies for hand-sewing mini pillows (fabric, thread, stuffing, etc. or ready-made pillow cases to decorate, if available), fabric crayons, newspaper, an electric iron

Project:
Decorate or create for yourself a special Sweet-Dreams Pillow.  Cover it with whatever images, colors and words will help you sleep deeply.  Use your pillow to create your safe “nest” for your deep wonderful rests.

Materials:
Copies of a favorite guided relaxation to hand out (see page 5 for sample, audio tapes and tape recorder (optional)

Description:
This is not an art project.  It is a supplementary suggestion for help with sleeping.  Using a guided relaxation can be a marvelous way to relax and fall asleep, when you feel tense or unable to sleep.  The relaxation can be recorded, or memorized.  For those who have tape players, it is wonderful to have the relaxation on tape, so they can listen and fall asleep, rather than trying to remember the relaxation.  Distribute copies of the sample relaxation, and encourage participants to take their copy with them and to change it as they wish.  If taping is possible, you might set up the equipment for this in a separate room.  That way, those who wish to make themselves a sleep relaxation tape may do so, one at a time, throughout the art workshop.   


Guided Relaxation for Peaceful Sleep
Lay comfortably in your bed, ready for sleep.  Adjust your arms and legs so that they are comfortable and settled. Notice your breathing...Now take some deep breaths in, and as you let each one out, say to yourself, “relax”...  

When you are ready, become aware of your face.  Notice your whole head and neck.  Now take a deep breath in, and squeeze the muscles in your face, head, and neck.  Now let your breath go and release all the tension from your head.  As you relax your head, picture the relaxation spreading through your entire body.  

Repeat above sequence for these:
*shoulders and back*  
*arms and hands*  
*chest and stomach*
*legs and feet*

Now take another deep breath for your entire body.  Gently tense the muscles from head to toe, one more time, and release.  Feel the tension melting away with your breath.  

Rest comfortably in this position.  Just enjoy how relaxed your whole body is, as you drift off to a deep, peaceful and refreshing sleep.
I would suggest adapting the key-tags' meaning to be a personal symbol for them to represent themselves.

Row.str_name: Muñecas (o figuras) de Hojas de Maíz
Row.txt_code:
Historial:
Las hojas son interesantes y divertidas para trabajar. Ellas pueden ser ronzadas o estiradas en una variedad de formas. Ellas pueden ser hechas rodar y atadas o rizadas. Ellas pueden ser dejadas naturales, pintadas o teñidas.

Algunos indios americanos usaban las hojas de maíz para tejer la ropa y para guardar alimentos en la cocina. Ellas actúan como embalaje natural, guardando lo húmedo y lo dulce del grano. Quizás usted ha comido tamales, un alimento hispano cocido al vapor en hojas de maíz.

Objetivo:
Este taller les brinda a las participantes la oportunidad de ser creativas, mientras que exploran temas culturales y del otoño.

Materiales:
Hojas de maíz (al menos 5 por muñeca)
Un tazón grande de agua para remojar las hojas
Toallas de papel en cada estación para absorber el agua de las hojas de maíz al primero sacarlas del tazón de agua.
Rafia, cordeles o hilados finos para el cabello
Tijeras. Nota: Algunas sugerencias opcionales requieren más materiales.

Nota: También se pueden utilizar las hojas de maíz frescas. Si desea hacerlo así guárdelas en un sitio donde se puedan secar bien hasta que esté lista para hacer el taller.

Introduccion:
El cambio de las estaciones marca la oportunidad de meditar y reflexionar sobre lo que es importante para nosotros. El otoño es la época de cosecha en el hemisferio norte, y un tiempo para reflexionar sobre lo que hemos cosechado en nuestras vidas a través de nuestras acciones. Las muñecas de hojas de maíz son un símbolo maravilloso para las semillas que hemos sembrado y cosechado en el último año.

Círculo de Abertura:
Meditación de Otoño

Para comenzar la meditación de la cosecha dígales a los participantes que se sienten rectas y lo más cómodas posible. Pídales que cierren los ojos si esto es algo cómodo para ellas. Pídales que pongan sus manos sobre los muslos y que empiecen a tomar respiraciones para establecerse.

Diga, "Inhale por 3 cuentas; mantenga por 3 cuentas, exhale por 4 cuentas." (Usted puede contar en voz alta si quiere). Haga esto varias veces hasta que la habitación se sienta quieta y callada. Entonces, siga "Comience a reconocer con aprecio lo que ha cosechado en su vida. Inhale 3 cuentas; mantenga 3 cuentas, exhale 4 cuentas. Todos hemos tenido metas, sueños y deseos en cuales hemos estado trabajando el último año. Imagínelos. Inhale 3 cuentas; mantenga 3 cuentas, exhale 4 cuentas. Si usted tiene una meta de largo plazo, es posible que la haya dividido en piezas más manejables - pequeños pasos hacia el éxito. Mírese a sí misma, como si usted se está viendo del punto de vista de otra persona, tomando estas medidas y estos pasos. Pueden haber habido obstáculos o retrocesos a lo largo de su viaje. Piense en lo que estas barreras o retrocesos-les enseñaron. Para algunas de nosotras puede haber sido la paciencia. Para otras, puede haber sido una forma nueva de pensar. ¿Qué es lo que le enseñaron a usted? Inhale 3 cuentas; mantenga 3 cuentas, exhale 4 cuentas. Piense que cada paso positivo que toma la lleva a otro paso, y así va construyendo una vida llena de alegría y felicidad. Mírese a si misma bañada en una luz radiante. Inhale 3 cuentas; mantenga 3 cuentas, exhala 4 cuentas. Reconozca que no hay mayor recompensa que alguien pueda obtener en la cosecha de la vida, que ser capaz de ver una recompensa de la armonía y de paz. Inhale 3 cuentas; mantenga 3 cuentas, exhale 4 cuentas. Refleje que todas estamos relacionadas entre sí y ayudándose unas a las otras para alcanzar los objetivos incita que estemos agregando al éxito del mundo en general. El equinoccio es un tiempo donde las horas de la noche y del día están en balance en ambos hemisferios. Vamos a aprovechar el tiempo en el que en el planeta todos tenemos esto en común para morar en nuestra identidad como una gran familia de la humanidad. "

 

Instrucciones:
Para ablandar las hojas antes de trabajar con ellas, se remojan en agua tibia durante unos minutos, y luego se ponen sobre una toallita de papel doblada, listas para el uso.

Sugerencia, teniendo presente: Haga todos los nudos con el cordel o la rafia sobre el mismo lado de la muñeca para una mirada más terminada. Todos los nudos pueden ser recortados al final o como usted vea, solamente asegúrese de hacer doble nudos apretados para cada uno antes de recortar los restos.

1: Capa 4 hojas de maíz una encima de la otra. (Las hojas más amplias trabajan mejor)
(Opcional, para añadir "pelo": coloque 20 hilos de la rafia entre el medio de esta capa con la longitud suplementaria hacia fuera el amplio final de las hojas. Las trenzas pueden ser añadidas al final como otra opción, ver instrucciones al final.)   

2: Empatar en la pulgada superior con una cuerda de rafia, fuertemente atada.

3: Tomar 2 hojas sobre cada lado y tire al revés entonces el nudo esta, ahora, dentro.

4: Para hacer una cabeza, empate un ensarte aproximadamente de una pulgada debajo la cumbre dada la vuelta formada por el nudo escondido debajo. El lazo de rafia se hace el cuello de la muñeca.

5: Para hacer los brazos, doble una hoja nueva en mitad longitudinal enrollada, (Las hojas de maíz más estrechas trabajan mejor y rollar con el grano de la hoja más bien que contra el grano). Ate cada final con un hilo de rafia.   

6: Colocar los brazos entre 2 de las hojas de maíz dentro del cuerpo de hojas de maíz. Deslice los brazos tan altos como ellas van suba hacia arriba el lazo de cuello.


7: Con una cuerda de rafia, ate una cintura debajo de los brazos. Átelo bastante fuertemente para sostener firmemente los brazos en su lugar.                                             

Opcional:
-Haga una muñeca con trenzas de coleta con 3 cuerdas de rafia, atadas a cada final. Empate la trenza en la muñeca en el cuello.
-Haga una muñeca/figura con pantalones más bien que una falda, cortando la falda el medio y atando cada lado en los tobillos
-Pinta la muñeca/figura.

Cierre del Círculo:
Dé la vuelta y pídale a las participantes que compartan sus muñecas de hoja de maíz y lo que estas muñecas representan para ellas en respecto a las cosechas de su otoño.

Recently when I was working with a group that was getting ready to leave the shelter, we did the Survival Masks project.  

Most of the participants chose to split the face on the mask.  They created one side to represent what they came to the shelter as and the other side to represent what they were leaving with.  

It was incredibly powerful for them to actually see the difference and acknowledge their growth.  It was fascinating for all of us to see their change so clearly.  

When they left the shelter they very carefully packed their art work between their clothing, so they could keep it protected!

I lead Windows workshops with pregnant teens. They call me ‘The Art Lady!’ and are excited when I arrive at the Center.  

Doing the Debut CD project, I asked the girls to create a CD that would express the message that they want to tell their child.  After the project, one of the teen moms who had been very dependant on her boyfriend said, ‘Never have a baby because you are lonely.’  This was a major moment of self-awareness for her.

It made me smile recently when one new girl told me she had heard about the Windows groups and she was looking forward to it because it would give her a break from ‘having’ to talk about feelings – but little did she know, they talk about feelings all the time through their art!

Intuition Dolls can be made using yarn instead of pipe-cleaners to create the body. 
To adapt this workshop to the new materials, use the following Materials List, Time Frame, and Technical Info.  The rest of the workshop (Objective, Introduction, etc.) can remain the same.






bronze, copper—
like the
desert

green—
deep rich moss in the
mountain forest

blue—
like
 the
sky
at
twilight
       
a
magical
time of transition



Materials List:
-Yarn - assorted colors
-Golden books - 1 per participant (to wrap yarn around)
-6"x12" fabric rectangles (as many colors, solids and prints as possible)
-Beads
-Old jewelry
-Fishing line     
-Fimo or Sculpey - colored
-Feathers
-Scissors - 1 per participant
-Jewelry pliers and wire cutters
-Paper and pens

Timeframe:
80-100 mins—Total time

10 mins—Snack and review group rules
10 mins—Check-in (name and what kind of animal you would like to be today?)
5-10 mins—Introduction and relaxation/visualization
10-15 mins—Make doll
10-15 mins—Make mask
10-15 mins—make dress (while mask bakes)
5 mins—Attatch hanger/stand
10-15 mins—Tie-on mask, jewels, feathers....
10 mins—Closing and checkout

Technical Info:     
Body
1.  Wrap yarn around long side of book, about 25-50 times
2.  At top of book, slip single strand of yarn under all loops.  Tie knot.
3.  Slip yarn off book. 



4.  Tie at "neck.”  Use single yarn, pull tight, tie knot, clip close or tie bow on top of knot.  This makes the doll’s "head."



5.  For "arms"-wrap yarn around short side of book.  Slip off book.  Tie at "wrist."  Clip and trim loops to create "hands."
6.  Insert "arms" through middle (chest area) of yarn loops.  Push up close to "neck joint."  Tie tightly at "waist."



7.  Make "legs"—if desired—Divide "skirt" in half.  Tie at "ankle.” Trim and shape "feet."



8.  Doll is ready for clothing, hanger, mask, adornment...

Mask
1.  Start with base color.  Pinch off a piece, the size of a marble.
2.  Roll into a ball.  Smash flat, about the size of a silver dollar. This is your base to work on.
3.  Use other colors for face details.  Set in beads. Don't worry too much about whether or not it looks like a face—Let it be symbolic.  Use colors, shapes and designs to represent your intuition.
4.  When your mask is ready, hold it up to your doll to be sure the size is what you want.  Adjust as needed.
5.  Use a toothpick or bead headpin to poke 2 holes on sides of mask.  (To tie mask on after it’s baked.)
6.  Bake masks 10-15 mins at 250 degrees.
7.  While masks are baking, (do not overbake!) and cooling (5-10 min), clean-up Sculpey and make clothes for doll.  Wash hands after using Sculpey or Fimo.

Doll Clothes
1.  Use pattern to cut dress.
2.  Cut fringe if you wish.
3.  Cut SMALL neck hole. (You can trim it a little if it's too small, but you can't add any back on if it's too big!)
4.  Slide dress over head.  Use yarn to tie around waist.  Adjust gathers, if necesary.
5.  Make more than one dress, and dress her in layers, if desired.

Hanger/Stand
1.  Attach hanger/stand after putting clothes on and before putting on mask, feathers, and jewels.
2.  Put pipecleaner thru a few of the yarns at top of head.  Bend the end up 1/2" or so and twist to secure.
3.  About two thirds of the way down pipe cleaner, bend and make one-inch loop.  Secure loose end tightly.
4.  Now doll can hang on wall or in window.  You can also bend it at a 90-degree angle, so that you can "sit" it on the table.  Adjust pipecleaner as needed for support.
5.  Use fishing line to tie on mask. Tie it quite tightly.  Stick feather behind mask, into yarn.  Add jewels, beads, etc.
6.  When you are done, take a few minutes to write a few words about your intuition doll and what it means to you.
Welcome each participant to use this technique to create the sense of water, and draw anything (not necessarily lilies) on the water’s surface.
The participants may wish to string their “gems.”  Make openings with a round, wooden, toothpick, which can remain in place during baking.  Use ribbon or other materials for stringing.

This technique works beautifully on many surfaces.  Use flat mat boards, metal cans, and even glass bottles, cups or jars.  If you are using glass, you might find the tissue paper sticks well, but not the magazine images.  It can be beautiful to work with just the tissue paper and add designs with crayons or pens.

If you are not able to spray paint the gold or silver, and the final clear sealer, you can still do the project, simply using the acrylic paints.  The finished ornaments will just have a less professional look.
Instead of spraying and painting the ornaments you could use colored sculpey clay on the balls and leave as is.

If you are not able to find glass ball ornaments to use, you can simply use the super sculpey to create ornaments.  Participants can make their own shapes from scratch.  Flat shapes, (like cookie cut-outs) will probably work best.  (Round shapes may take too much sculpey and too long to cook).   If you are using the sculpey alone, you will need paper clips to embed in the top of each ornament to provide a hook.  Also, provide hooks to attach the ornament to the tree, if possible.
Have them draw their father.  Ask the child what they feel about their father.  (A volunteer would have to help the younger ones as they do this.)

With an older group of children or a group of adults, provide a wide range of colors and encourage the members to have each color symbolize an area of their life. Have them explain their color key during closing circle.

Row.str_name: Happiness in My Heart (A Variation for All Year Round)
Row.txt_code:
The Inner Gifts workshop doesn’t have to be done around the Holidays.  It can be adapted for all year round, giving the kids a special tool they can use to find the happiness in their heart when things are upsetting.    It’s called “Happiness in My Heart&rdqu o; and you might try it any time of year.  

Materials and Prep:  
This workshop can use the same simple supplies as Inner Gifts (see page 2) with each child creating a figure with a window into their heart.  

OR

Instead of using the gingerbread man pattern, you could just focus on the heart only.  Cut out large hearts and have the children simply decorate their hearts to show what is inside.

Introduction:
“When difficult things happen to us we can feel confused and scared. Sometimes it’s hard to calm down and think clearly.  In those difficult times, it can help if we look deep inside ourselves to try to find the happiness and safety deep down in our hearts.  That’s what this workshop is about.  It will be a chance to look for that safe, happy place inside ourselves.  It could be the thought of something that makes us feel happy and strong, a sport we love to play, a time we laughed and laughed.  It could be anything that warms our heart with happiness.”  

Relaxation:  
“Take a deep breath and put your hand on your heart.  Rest it there as you take another deep breath.  You can close your eyes if you want to.  

“Now picture something that makes you feel happy, or something you are thankful for.  It could be the face of someone you love or whatever you love to think of.

“Imagine it filling up your heart.  Feel that happiness filling your heart so full it’s overflowing.  

“And now picture it filling your whole body – all your joy and happiness and good feeling…

“And now picture it filling up the whole room!  All your happiness, filling the room so full it’s going to burst!

“And now picture it shining out from the room to the whole world.  Shining all the way from inside your heart out to the whole world around you.  

“Take a moment to notice how wonderful it feels, and when you’re ready, open your eyes.”  

Creation:
“When you’re ready, open your eyes and create drawing of the happiness you found in your heart!”

Closing:  
Give everyone a chance to share about what is in their heart.

At the AWBW leader’s workshop the following adaptation was suggested:
 
The face masks could be painted on the inside to represent the struggles the children are facing and on the outside to express what they want in their future.  The children could also cut out words to collage onto their faces.

At the AWBW leader’s workshop the following adaptation was suggested:

The hand masks could be adapted along the theme “hands are not for hitting.”  The children could explore all the good things hands are for and experience their hands in a new way as their mask is made.

Intuition Dolls can be made using yarn instead of pipe-cleaners to create the body. 
To adapt this workshop to the new materials, use the following Materials List, Time Frame, and Technical Info.  The rest of the workshop (Objective, Introduction, etc.) can remain the same.





bronze, copper—
like the desert

green—
deep rich moss in the mountain forest

blue—
like the sky at twilight

a magical time of transition

2.  Put pipe cleaner thru a few of the yarns at top of head.  Bend the end up 1/2" or so and twist to secure.
3.  About two-thirds of the way down pipe cleaner, bend and make one-inch loop.  Secure loose end tightly.
4.  Now doll can hang on wall or in window.  You can also bend it at a 90-degree angle, so that you can "sit" it on table.  Adjust pipe cleaner as needed for support.
5.  Use fishing line to tie on mask. Tie it quite tightly.  Stick feather behind mask, into yarn.  Add jewels, beads, etc.
6.  When you are done, take a few minutes to write a few words about your intuition doll and what it means to you.

Ask the children to draw a landscape where they feel safe.  Mountains, trees, sky, etc., look wonderful with this watercolor-resist technique.   They could do their drawings, then water them with the spray, and then add the colors.

Ask the children what kind of rose bush they would be, if they were a rose bush.  Would they have thorns?  Would they have flowers?  Would it be dark around them?  Would the sun be shining on them?  They could draw their rose bush, water it with the spray water, and then add the paint.

You could ask the children to scratch into their pictures an imaginary animal.  “Would it have wings?  Would it have teeth?  Would it have a tail?  What can you make up?  What does your imaginary animal do?  Does your imaginary animal have a name?  Is it friendly?  Can your animal talk?  What would it say if it could talk?”

Instead of drawing the light mud on paper, you could use magazine images.  Each child could pick a magazine image as their first layer.  Then they could make “mud” over the image, and then scratch through to the picture.  (Be sure to test this process out yourself first, before leading it!)

This technique can be used to create all sorts of images.  If the kids spontaneously start creating pictures that aren’t fish, be sure to encourage them and let them know it’s safe to create whatever they want.

You could ask the children to scratch their names into their picture, and decorate it however they think expresses who
they are.

This technique can be used to create all sorts of images.  If the kids spontaneously start creating pictures that aren’t fish, be sure to encourage them and let them know it’s safe to create whatever they want.

Encourage the children to make stick people families.  Encourage them to be creative with the stick people, putting hair on them, or whatever else they wish.

This technique can be used to create all sorts of images.  If the kids spontaneously start creating pictures that aren’t fish, be sure to encourage them and let them know it’s safe to create whatever they want. 

Encourage the children to make a family out of flowers:  big ones, little ones.  “How would the flowers be together?”

This technique can be used to create all sorts of images.  If the kids spontaneously start creating pictures that aren’t fish, be sure to encourage them and let them know it’s safe to create whatever they want.
 
You could encourage the children to draw a picture of their own face.  How do their faces look today?  Is it happy?  Is it sad?  Is it mad?  Is it sleepy?

Tree etching with white paint only





Tree etching with many colors


After you cover the page with white paint, add other colors to paint the image of a tree.  Then use the fork, knife and spoon to scratch lines into their drawing.  What kind of lines would they like to put on the tree’s trunk?  How about the leaves?  Is there grass underneath?  Note:  If you are painting the images of a tree before scratching into it, it’s important to keep the paint pretty thin.  If it’s too thick, the scratched lines will fill themselves in and dissappear.

In shelters where it is possible to conduct separate workshops for the older children and the younger children, it will add depth to the workshop to give more specific directives for the facepainting when working with adolescents as a group.  For example, teenagers can be told the following directive to add context to the activity:

“On the paper, divide your face down the middle.  Draw one side the way you are on the outside (the face that you show the world) and on the other side draw the way you are on the inside (which people don’t usually see).  Have your partner paint your face this way.  Or choose one of the two and have your entire face painted that way.”

It is up to the Leader to decide what projects would be most useful and valuable for any particular group of shelter residents.

In this warm up the participants can write a letter to themselves with help from the other participants.  For this variation you will need a piece of nice paper or stationary and pen.  Everyone starts by writing Dear and their own name.
Give them 1 or 2 minutes to write one or two senteces to themselves.  Participants will then fold the paper over to cover their name and their original sentence(s) (you may want to use a little piece of scotch tape to keep the name anonymous). 

Once everyone is done you can put the letters in the middle of the table and have particpants take one and add another sentence or two. Repeat this process 2 or 3 times then return it to the original person. The original person can then add a closing and sign it.

Every age group loves Shrinky-dinks however you may consider incorporating the following workshops for pre-school age children. You may do a combination of Journey Butterflies for your older childrens while the preschoolers create the My Butterfly Workshop (January 2001) or Watercolor Butterfly Journeys (May 2005). You can start with the same warm-up the delinate separate spaces for the different age groups.  You can then explain the creation process to each group.

This warm up is from Karen Johnson of The Alaska Family Resource Center.

Have the children wrap up in towels and move around flapping their "wings" so their muscles can grow as they turn into butterflies. Discuss with the children how important it is to work your own way out of the cocoon on your own strength verses someone else doing all the work. Butterflies fly because they have strong muscles.

If you don't have access to t-shirts, you can easily do this workshop with paper t-shirts. Simply download the paper t-shirt template below, or create your own t-shirt templates and enjoy. Use string and small clothespins to create the same effect as the regular Clothesline Project workshop.
Paper T-shirt template

   
   
   
  Mini Clothesline Project with paper t-shirts!

Create mini versions of The Clothesline Project with Shrinky-Dink paper! Simply download the t-shirt template below. Participants can make keepsake necklaces and bracelets with ribbon and beads to wear and remind themselves of the statements they made. They'll make great conversation-starters!
Shrinky-Dink template

 
 
   
   
  Clothesline Project with Shrinky-Dink t-shirts!

Shrinky with pinback
 
  
 Different Shrinky Dink pins!
 
You can also use the pocket templates to make Shrinky- Dink pockets to have as pins.

Pocket Template
Awareness Ribbon Template

This workshop can be followed in the same manner, just make sure you have a toaster oven, colored pencils, scissors and permanent markers. Pinbacks that are already adhesive work the best, they can found at any crafting store.

Objective:
To give the children an opportunity to create a painting that represents strength and protection on a Native American style shield, so that they can explore what protection means to them and what it might look like.

Materials:
Native American style shields
various fabric paint
stencils
stencil brushes
regular brushes
cups of water
pens
paper to cover the tables
Native American music

Note: (AWBW can provide you with FREE Native American music by Carlos Reynos if you request it!)

Time Frame:
1 - 1 1/2 hours

Set-up:
Lay out all material on the table and have music ready to play during the workshop.

Introduction:
Shields were once used as a source of protection by people all over the world. The shields varied in size, shapes, and design. Today we are going to create a Native American style Protective Shield that represents strength and protection for us. Can you think of a time that you felt like you needed protection? Or a time that you wanted to protect someone else because you felt like they might get hurt?

Opening Circle:
Have the children to do a brief introduction of themselves. In this way everyone knows everyone’s name and it helps to break the ice if there are any new participants. They can also share their thoughts about protection. Have the children talk about what protection means to them. Ask them what it might look like...what represents strength and protection for them...what colors, images, or words they might use for protection.

Creation:
Show them a sample Protective Shield to give them an idea of what they are going to be doing. Show them the materials and colors they can use and how to use them. You can give them the option of a few stencils of bear and other animal foot steps, a sun, or a figure for example. Then turn on some Native American music and tell them to think back to what protection means and looks like to them. Tell them to visualize the colors and images that come to them and draw or paint them on the shield.

Closing:
After the children are all done making their own shield, have them talk about their finished shield, what images and colors they put on it and what they mean to them. Encourage each child to share, but make sure no one feels forced. They need to feel secure that no one will ridicule them in order to open up. You may even talk to them about where they may want to place the shield for protection or display.

Row.str_name: Sand Masks and Sand Feeling Jars
Row.txt_code:
Sand Masks:
A variation for the Sand Painting workshop could be to use the colored sand to create colorful masks using mask templates (see below).

Sand Feeling Jars:
Another variation could be to use babyfood, jam jars or small clear bottles to create Sand Feeling Jars. Participants can connect a feeling to each color they use to represent their emotions. One would pour the sand in, level it, and then pour in another color and repeat this process until the jar is full.

   
  Sample Sand Feelings Jar and Sand Mask

Row.str_name: Sand Masks and Sand Feeling Jars
Row.txt_code:
Sand Masks:
A variation for the Sand Painting workshop could be to use the colored sand to create colorful masks using mask templates (see below).

Sand Feeling Jars:
Another variation could be to use babyfood, jam jars or small clear bottles to create Sand Feeling Jars. Participants can connect a feeling to each color they use to represent their emotions. One would pour the sand in, level it how they want it, and then pour in another color and repeat this until the jar is full.

   
  Sample Sand Feelings Jar and Sand Mask

This variation is an exercise in taking care of yourself through making natural facials! The workshop allows participants to relax and focus on what it means to take care of themselves.

The facials can become symbolic when asking “What is it that you want to absorb, what is it tha t you want to put into your body and life?” As the participants create and enjoy their facials generate a conversation about how it feels to take care of ourselves.  Just like each person may require a different facial depending on their skin type, each person should think about their own individual ways in which they can and would like to take care of themselves in addition to the facials.

Formulas for Natural Facials:
1. MASKS:
FOR SENSITIVE SKIN:
1 Cup Natural Yogurt
½ Cup Oatmeal
Mix, Apply to skin for 15 minutes

FOR OILY SKIN:
Add drops of lemon or lime juice to #1 above

FOR DRY SKIN:
Add a couple of Tablespoons Honey to # 1 above

Wash off mask with Warm Water

2.  MOISTURIZING:
1/2 Avocado
¼ cup Honey
Mash together
Apply to skin for 5 – 10 minutes
Rinse with washcloth drenched in cool water.

Special thanks to Janet Chaize and Leila Zureiqi from Alternatives for Battered Women, NY for sharing this variation with us.

Objective:
To provide participants with an opportunity to create a "window into Peace". This is a chance for each of us to envision a world full of peace. To give ourselves time to think about what peace means and what the world might look like if anything were possible and peace was all we knew. This window will be a piece of the puzzle we can take with us to remember our vision of peace and hold it in our hearts, only letting it go to create a ripple of love into the world.

Relaxation
"Take a deep breath...and let it go...Take another deep breath, and as you let it go, notice yourself sinking into your chair... Notice the chair holding you, supporting you, as you relax...Take another deep breath and feel your feet sinking into the floor. Feel the floor gently holding your feet, so that you can rest... Take another deep breath, and as you exhale, notice yourself relaxing even more, sinking into your chair, resting...This is your time, just for you. As you breathe deeply and relax, begin to picture a beautiful window that you are drawn to...feel yourself gazing out the window into a world of peace...notice what you see, what colors peace has...are they dark or light, foggy or clear, what does peace look like for you...what does it sound like...what does peace feel like...as you slowly open your eyes, hold onto your vision and reach for images that feel intuitively right for you to create your window into peace."

Technical Information:
The creation of the magnets is a step-by-step process, which can be most efficiently explained and demonstrated once for everyone to see before they begin to create their magnets. The basic steps are as follows:

1. Select an image or images you wish to collage and select a piece of plexiglass.

2. Cut the magazine images you like and collage them onto the poster board piece. Make sure that you are attaching the images to the correct side of the poster board piece so that you will be able to put the clear glass right over the images. Use the scissors and the glue sticks for the collaging.

3. When the collage is complete on the piece of poster board, remove the protective paper from the plexiglass.

4. Check the fit of the board and glass. Trim the board and magazine images if necessary.

5. Use a brush to cover the face of the magazine images with Matte Medium. It will look like you're ruining the collage by making it all white. Don't worry - the Matte Medium dries clear.

6. Press the plexiglass onto the surface of the magazines. Squeeze excess Matte Medium and air bubbles out to the sides of the glass. Be careful not to get Matte Medium on the front surface of the glass - it will show. (Keep your fingers squeaky clean...) Also, be careful to match the edges of the board and glass up as you press. Once they are pressed together, you won't be able to slide them into alignment.

7. Hold the board and glass together for about 3 minutes as it begins to dry. When you are able to lift your pressure without seeing a whole bunch of air bubbles enter the image, take your hands off and let it sit.

8. Attach the magnet to the back of the board by taking off the protective covering of the magnet...it will easily stick to the board.

Creation:
After demonstrating this process, assist participants in making a magnet for themselves.

Closing:
This exercise can be closed informally or formally as seems appropriate. If possible, it is powerful to have a circle during which each person can share what he or she made, what it felt like for them, and what they gained from the session.

**We could end with one word from participants on what peace felt like for them.

Purpose
To explore, express, reflect, and record your feelings through journal entries. Remember that you don't have to share your work. You're in charge!

Materials
Journal books
Pens for writi ng and colored felt pens to illustrate journals
Yellow markers or highlighters
Magazines, scissors, and glue (optional items to personalize journals)
independent project handout (for individual workshop) (click here for handout)

Welcome and Ground Rules
It can help create a safe environment if you take time to individually welcome each teen, connect with them, and let them know you are glad they are there. Introduce the project and the philosophy of Windows time: "This is a special "window of time" for each of you. For Windows time, we have some Ground Rules to help create respect and safety. Can anyone think of a Ground Rule that would help? Are there any other Ground Rules you'd like to add?" At this time you can mention any pre-established ground rules you have.

Check-In
A good example of an appropriate check-in would be: "Before we start the art, we'll have a check-in circle so everyone has a chance to share their name, how they are feeling today, and any feelings about doing art." This is a time to reassure anyone who's scared of art that it's fine, and to tell anyone who "hates" art that's fine too. Remind them that they don't have to do it, that they can just watch if they want to. When given the freedom, they will probably choose to join in even if they say they're just going to watch. Let them know that it's fine if they don't want to say anything for "check-in", too.

Note to Leaders
Always offer options and thank teens for their courage. Having colored markers and collaging supplies can give the teens more options for exploring their feelings if they are having a hard time writing.

Project Suggestion
"Write three pages in a non-stop manner about something that happened this week and how you feel about it. Don't worry about spelling, punctuation, or how it sounds. If you get stuck, write, 'I don't know what to write' and keep coming back to the topic at hand. Remember, don't stop writing!"
Sample:
"I don't know what to write but the topic is to write about today and today was a good day but also a hard day and a day I'll always remember and I might wish to someday forget. My clothes are a bit tight but that is not the topic and I don't know what to write but I'll come back to how my day went and I didn't like it when Mom yelled at me but I love her and can I love her and not like what she does?"
Second Section:
Re-read what you wrote and highlight with the yellow marker anything that seems particularly interesting, powerful, or strange. Write three more pages based on the words or sections that you marked using the same non-stop format. This second section helps deepen your self-awareness.
Third Section (time permitting):
Use colored felt pens to illustrate your journal entries.

Optional Feedback Exercise
Ten minutes before the workshop ends, pass out one sheet of paper per person. Ask the teens to write a paragraph about what they learned from the workshop. Ask permission to read these papers so you can learn about the effectiveness of the workshop. You could even take them to copy and return them the next week, so that the teens can add them to their journals.

Closure and Validation
At the end of the project, a Closing Circle can be a way to give each teen an opportunity to share what she or he has created and talk about what it means to them and how it felt to make it. Just like the check-in circle, give each teen a chance to speak. Validate their courage for opening themselves up to their own creativity and respecting whatever came out.

Purpose
To explore writing in a way that helps you feel especially free from all judgment - even your own judgment.

Materials
Timer
Journal books
Pens for writing and colored felt pens to illustrate journals
Magazines, scissors, and glue (optional items to personalize journals)

Setup
Set out the supplies, with a journal and pens at each place. 

Welcome and Ground Rules
It can help create a safe environment if you take time to individually welcome each teen, connect with them, and let them know you are glad they are there.  Introduce the project and the philosophy of Windows time: "This is a special "window of time" for each of you.  For Windows time, we have some Ground Rules to help create respect and safety.  Can anyone think of a Ground Rule that would help?  Are there any other Ground Rules you'd like to add?"  At this time you can mention any pre-established ground rules you have. 

Check-In
A good example of an appropriate check-in would be: "Before we start the art, we'll have a check-in circle so everyone has a chance to share their name, how they are feeling today, and any feelings about doing art."  This is a time to reassure anyone who's scared of art that it's fine, and to tell anyone who "hates" art that's fine too.  Remind them that they don't have to do it, that they can just watch if they want to.  When given the freedom, they will probably choose to join in even if they say they're just going to watch.  Let them know that it's fine if they don't want to say anything for "check-in", too.

Note to Leaders
Always offer options and thank the teens for their courage.  You can offer a theme for the whole group to work with, or encourage each teen to chose his or her own theme.  Having colored markers and collaging supplies can give the teens more options for exploring their feelings if they are having a hard time writing.

Project Suggestion
"In this workshop, you can explore writing freely, without judgment or criticism.  You can start with a theme phrase (such as "I am..." or "I feel..." or whatever theme seems right to explore).  Begin with your theme phrase, and write whatever comes to mind.  To help you be as free as possible, there are some rules.  You don't really have to follow them, bu tif you do, you might find that they help you write.  Here are the three rules: 1) Write for the full time without stopping (that's why we have a timer); 2) Write whatever your first thoughts are, even if you don't like them; and 3) Write without crossing out or changing anything.  Just let it be.  Let this writing be different from anything you've ever written.  Spelling doesn't matter.  It's even fine if you just scribble the whole time.  The only important thing is that you give yourself freedom and practice respecting whatever comes out.
Decide on the amount of time for writing (5-10 minutes is usually pretty good to try out).  Set your timer.  Get ready.  And go!  After the timer goes off, you can take some time to read back over what you wrote.  Reading it out loud to someone can be powerful.  If you don't want to read it all, you can read parts of it and share your thoughts and feelings about it."

Optional Feedback Exercise
Ten minutes before the workshop ends, pass out one sheet of paper per person.  Ask the teens to write a paragraph about what they learned from the workshop.  Ask permission to read these papers so you can learn about the effectiveness of the workshop.  You could even take them to copy and return them the next week, so that the teens can add them to their journals.

Closing and Validation
At the end of the project, a Closing Circle can be a way to give each teen an opportunity to share what she or he has created and talk about what it means to them and how it felt to make it.  Just like the check-in circle, give each teen a chance to speak.  Validate their courage for opening themselves up to their own creativity and respecting whatever came out.

Purpose:
To explore three different feelings by creating three pastel drawings.

Materials:
9" by 6" Colored Construction Paper (standard 9" by 12" paper cut in half)
chalk pastels
masking tape
paper towels
pens and writing paper (optional: teens could use their journals)
independent project handout (for individual workshop) (click here for handout)

Welcome and Ground Rules:
It can help create a safe environment if you take time to individually welcome each teen, connect with them, and let them know you are glad they are there. Introduce the project and the philosophy of Windows time: "This is a special "window of time" for each of you. For Windows time, we have some Ground Rules to help create respect and safety. Can anyone think of a Ground Rule that would help? Are there any other Ground Rules you'd like to add?" At this time you can mention any pre-established ground rules you have.

Check In:
A good example of an appropriate check-in would be: "Before we start the art, we'll have a check-in circle so everyone has a chance to share their name, how they are feeling today, and any feelings about doing art." This is a time to reassure anyone who's scared of art that it's fine, and to tell anyone who "hates" art that's fine too. Remind them that they don't have to do it, that they can just watch if they want to. When given the freedom, they will probably choose to join in even if they say they're just going to watch. Let them know that it's fine if they don't want to say anything for "check-in", too.

Optional Journaling:
"Write for five minutes about whatever feelings you've been having lately. Can you remember any good feelings? Any bad feelings? Write about them."

Project Suggestion:
"This workshop is a chance to explore feelings with chalk pastels. Pick three feelings from this list: love, hate, peace, anger, sadness, joy. Notice which feelings you would like to explore today. Write them down. If you want to pick a feeling that's not on the list, that's fine too! Now choose three pieces of paper to represent these three feelings, and tape the edges down with masking tape in front of you. When you are ready, begin with one of the feelings. Use the chalk pastels to create whatever shapes and colors express that feeling. Try covering the page with a color and smearing the pastels with your fingers. See how smooth it can look when you blend the colors together. When you are ready, move onto the second feeling. Use the shapes and colors of the pastels to create the world of that feeling. Remember, if you notice any critical thoughts coming into your head, send them into the Self-Critical Trash Can. When you are ready, explore the third feeling, and when all three are finished, take some time to write any words that go with your pastel windows."

Optional Feedback Exercise:
Ten minutes before the workshop ends, pass out one sheet of paper per person. Ask the teens to write a paragraph about what they learned from the workshop. Ask permission to read these papers so you can learn about the effectiveness of the workshop. You could even take them to copy and return them the next week, so that the teens can have them or add them to journals they might be keeping.

Closure and Validation:
At the end of the project, a Closing Circle can be a way to give each teen an opportunity to share what she or he has created and talk about what it means to them and how it felt to make it. Just like the check-in circle, give each teen a chance to speak. Validate their courage for opening themselves up to their own creativity and respecting whatever came out.

Purpose:
To explore different feelings by creating three small watercolor paintings.

Materials:
4" X 4" watercolor paper (three per person)
watercolor paint sets (one per person)
brushes
cups of water (two per person)
paper towels
masking tape
pens and writing paper (teens could also use their journals instead)
independent project handout (for individual workshops) (click here for handout)

Set Up:
Make sure that there are three pieces of watercolor paper, two cups of water, and a watercolor paint set and brushes at each place. If possible, tape down the pieces of watercolor paper at each place with masking tape before the workshop begins.

Welcome and Ground Rules
It can help create a safe environment if you take time to individually welcome each teen, connect with them, and let them know you are glad they are there. Introduce the project and the philosophy of Windows time: "This is a special "window of time" for each of you. For Windows time, we have some Ground Rules to help create respect and safety. Can anyone think of a Ground Rule that would help? Are there any other Ground Rules you'd like to add?" At this time you can mention any pre-established ground rules you have.

Check In
A good example of an appropriate check-in would be: "Before we start the art, we'll have a check-in circle so everyone has a chance to share their name, how they are feeling today, and any feelings about doing art." This is a time to reassure anyone who's scared of art that it's fine, and to tell anyone who "hates" art that's fine too. Remind them that they don't have to do it, that they can just watch if they want to. When given the freedom, they will probably choose to join in even if they say they're just going to watch. Let them know that it's fine if they don't want to say anything for "check-in", too.

Optional Journaling
"Write for five minutes about whatever feelings you've been having lately. Can you remember any good feelings? Any bad feelings? Write about them."

Project Suggestion
"This workshop is a chance to explore feelings with watercolor paints. With watercolors, it can be very beautiful if you start by creating a shape out of pure water, and then add colors into it. You can't control what the colors will do, so it's amazing to just watch. Take three pieces of watercolor paper and tape the edges down. This will help hold them flat while you are painting. Now pick three feelings from this list: love, hate, peace, anger, sadness, joy. If you want to pick a feeling that is not on this list, that's fine too!
Start with your first piece of paper and begin by making a shape on your page out of clear water - a shape that represents the first feeling you picked. Put enough water so it's like a little lake. Then begin to add colors into the lake, and around it. Notice how the colors move. Flow with them to express the feeling.
When you're ready, move onto the next feeling you chose. On a second piece of paper, create a shape of water representing this feeling and add colors in and around it. When you are ready, move on to the final feeling and create your third watercolor window. Let the watercolors dry before removing the tape. As they dry, you might write down any words that go with your three windows."

Optional Feedback Exercise
Ten minutes before the workshop ends, pass out one sheet of paper per person. Ask the teens to write a paragraph about what they learned from the workshop. Ask permission to read these papers so you can learn about the effectiveness of the workshop. You could even take them to copy and return them the next week, so that the teens can add them to their journals.

Closing and Validation
At the end of the project, a Closing Circle can be a way to give each teen an opportunity to share what she or he has created and talk about what it means to them and how it felt to make it. Just like the check-in circle, give each teen a chance to speak. Validate their courage for opening themselves up to their own creativity and respecting whatever came out.

Row.str_name: Self-nurture Portraits en Español—Traducido por Allie Holsen
Row.txt_code:
Objetivo:
Los artistas han pintado retrasos de si mismas por muchos siglos. Este taller les da a las mujeres la oportunidad examinar sus caras, y sus identidades. También, este taller les deja pintar si mismas en la manera en la que quieren expresarse. El proyecto les ayuda a las mujeres darse cuenta de que ellas son “trabajos de arte” – que se den cuenta de su propio valor en cada manera que sea posible.

Introducción:
[Líder] Explica que cada una de nosotras nos mira al espejo diariamente, pero por la mayoría del tiempo no hacemos una pausa para ver nosotros mismas en una manera especial. No nos damos cuenta de que somos únicas, preciosas y maravillosas. Tanto como tenemos el poder cambiar el día de un mal día a un buen día, tenemos el poder el cual es lo más importante – desarrollar nosotros mismas y determinar como llegaremos al fin. Tenemos el poder decidir ser positivas y cariñoso. Tenemos el poder elegir el camino de vivir sin la violencia. Tenemos el poder transformar y nos convertiremos en la persona que deseamos ser.

Relajación:
Relájate en la silla y cierran los ojos. Imagínate que entras en un taller de una artista. Andas hacía una silla cómoda en el medio del taller. Puedes ver los retratos de personas famosas que están colgados por el taller. Empiezas a ver los retratos de personas desconocidas, pero éstos también te fascinan. La dueña del taller es una artista brillante y famosa es bien conocida por su trabajo con los retratos. Hoy, eres el sujeto de su retrato. E hoy, eres la artista brillante. Pintarás tu propio retrato.
Fíjate en mirar al espejo. Mira a tus ojos. Estos ojos han visto tantas cosas. ¿Qué tipo de cosas prefieres ver con más frecuencia? ¿Cuáles son las cosas las que te gustarían ver con menos frecuencia? Piensa en la nariz. Piensa en los olores…de tu comida favorita, las velas, flores, la lluvia. Ahora, piensa en la boca. Piensa en lo que hubieras dicho en el pasado. ¿Has dicho cosas doloras anteriormente? ¿Cómo te sentías? ¿Cuándo hubieras dicho cosas buenas, cómo te sentías? También piensa en la lengua y las papilas del gusto. ¿Cuáles son los tipos de comida que te disfrutas? ¿Un bistec o una rica torta del chocolate? Piensa en las comidas que te dan consuelo. Piensa en los oídos. ¿Cómo se te ven?
Ahora, empiece a pensar en lo que tus oídos han oído. Fíjate en todo de los sonidos que han pasado por los oídos y tu mente: el sonido de la bocina, susurros, música, silencio, gritos, argumentos, los pájaros gorjeando, los bebes llorando, la risa de los niños, el océano, escuchando a alguien que te diga: te amo. Piensa en estas cosas y como te sientes cuando las oyes.

Finalmente, piensa en tu cara y la piel. La piel es el órgano más grande en nuestro cuerpo. Piensa en las sensaciones de la piel – el dolor y la alegría. ¿Cuáles son las sensaciones que has disfrutado: un beso en la mejilla, poner la cabeza encima de una almohada, envolviéndote en una manta, un masaje del pie, un gran abrazo? El cuerpo puede sentir y aceptar estímulo – muchos tipos de estímulo – e hay muchas maneras en las que podemos reaccionar y sentir de muchas cosas en el mundo. Hay muchas complexidades sobre la mente y el cuerpo. Somos complejas por adentro y a fuera. Somos preciosas y únicas. Cuando los ojos se abran, mire al espejo, recuerde de tus complexidades y belleza. Celebra la belleza adentro y a fuera de ti, por crear tu auto-retrato.

Purpose:
To create a special book with three-dimensional laers of collaging that express different layers of yourself.

Materials:
6" X 9" construction paper (2 per person)
6" X 9" cardboard backing (2 per person)
9" X 1" strips of card stock (4-6 per person)
Magazines/photostock books
glue sticks
scissors
pens and writing paper (teens could also use their journals)
optional: if you can afford getting Mat-board frames (3 per person) you can use these for the layers.
independent project handout (for individual workshop) (click here for handout)

Welcome and Ground Rules:
It can help create a safe environment if you take time to individually welcome each teen, connect with them, and let them know you are glad they are there. Introduce the project and the philosophy of Windows time: "This is a special "window of time" for each of you. For Windows time, we have some Ground Rules to help create respect and safety. Can anyone think of a Ground Rule that would help? Are there any other Ground Rules you'd like to add?" At this time you can mention any pre-established ground rules you have.

Check In:
A good example of an appropriate check-in would be: "Before we start the art, we'll have a check-in circle so everyone has a chance to share their name, how they are feeling today, and any feelings about doing art." This is a time to reassure anyone who's scared of art that it's fine, and to tell anyone who "hates" art that's fine too. Remind them that they don't have to do it, that they can just watch if they want to. When given the freedom, they will probably choose to join in even if they say they're just going to watch. Let them know that it's fine if they don't want to say anything for "check-in", too.

Optional Journaling:
"Write for five minutes starting with the phrase 'My layers are...'. Write any thoughts that come to mind about the layers of who you are."

Note:
For this workshop, it's important to have a sample to show. Otherwise it can be too confusing to construct.

Project Suggestion:
"This workshop is a chance to explore different layers of yourself by creating a tunnel book (see sample). The tunnel book has layers from the front all the way to the back. We all have parts of ourselves that we keep more hidden and parts that we show. You can use the layers of your tunnel book to show the layers of yourself. For example, the very back of your tunnel book could show the you that you keep on the inside, and in the front you could show the you that the world sees. You can use the layers however it feels right to you."

Optional Feedback Exercise:
Ten minutes before the workshop ends, pass out one sheet of paper per person. Ask the teens to write a paragraph about what they learned from the workshop. Ask permission to read these papers so you can learn about the effectiveness of the workshop. You could even take them to copy and return them the next week, so that the teens can add them to their journals.

Closing and Validation:
At the end of the project, a Closing Circle can be a way to give each teen an opportunity to share what she or he has created and talk about what it means to them and how it felt to make it. Just like the check-in circle, give each teen a chance to speak. Validate their courage for opening themselves up to their own creativity and respecting whatever came out.

Purpose:
To create a jar to keep special messages in to use as a special source of support.

Materials:
newspaper (to cover table)
baby food jars (with labels removed - one per person)
paper plates (one per person, to use as a palette)
acrylic paints
brushes
water cups and paper towels (for rinsing brushes)
construction paper
pens and writing paper (teens could also use their journals)
independent project handout (for individual workshop) (click here for handout)

Set Up:
Clean the baby food jars and remove any excess paper or glue left over from the label. Cover the art area with newspaper and set the supplies around the table.

Welcome and Ground Rules:
It can help create a safe environment if you take time to individually welcome each teen, connect with them, and let them know you are glad they are there. Introduce the project and the philosophy of Windows time: "This is a special "window of time" for each of you. For Windows time, we have some Ground Rules to help create respect and safety. Can anyone think of a Ground Rule that would help? Are there any other Ground Rules you'd like to add?" At this time you can mention any pre-established ground rules you have.

Check In:
A good example of an appropriate check-in would be: "Before we start the art, we'll have a check-in circle so everyone has a chance to share their name, how they are feeling today, and any feelings about doing art." This is a time to reassure anyone who's scared of art that it's fine, and to tell anyone who "hates" art that's fine too. Remind them that they don't have to do it, that they can just watch if they want to. When given the freedom, they will probably choose to join in even if they say they're just going to watch. Let them know that it's fine if they don't want to say anything for "check-in", too.

Optional Journaling:
"Write for five minutes about the encouragement and support in your life. Where do you find support? Are there any special words someone has said that have helped you through tough times? What words do you like to hear when you need support? Write them down."

Project Suggestion:
"This workshop is a chance to create a special jar you can use as a source of support. It can be your 'happy jar', your 'memory jar', your 'power jar' - whatever you want to call it. It is yours. You can paint the outside of it with acrylic paints and put messages inside it that represent support and encouragement for you. Be sure to paint the lid too!
When you fill your jar with encouraging messages, you can ask friends and family to write messages for you and put them in your jar, too. Once you've finished your jar, keep it wherever you want and open it up whenever you are needing reminders of support and encouragement.

Optional Feedback Exercise:
Ten minutes before the workshop ends, pass out one sheet of paper per person. Ask the teens to write a paragraph about what they learned from the workshop. Ask permission to read these papers so you can learn about the effectiveness of the workshop. You could even take them to copy and return them the next week, so that the teens can add them to their journals.

Closing and Validation:
At the end of the project, a Closing Circle can be a way to give each teen an opportunity to share what she or he has created and talk about what it means to them and how it felt to make it. Just like the check-in circle, give each teen a chance to speak. Validate their courage for opening themselves up to their own creativity and respecting whatever came out.

A special thanks to Arianne Craven from Lydia Place for providing us with this exciting variation to Our Family Tree workshop!


Our Family Tree variation:
Having children make underwater sea creatures is an alternative way for them to make a family tree.  To adapt this workshop to the new materials, use the following Materials List and the Steps for the art project. The rest of the workshop (Objective, Time Frame, Space, Art Creation, Sharing Circle) can remain the same.

Materials List:
construction paper (various colors, preferably bright colors)
crayons, markers, pens, glitter pens, paint, glitter paint, paint brushes
masking tape (for hanging on the wall)
If you have access to clip art on the computer, look up different types of fish, seahorses, crabs, starfish, etc. If you don't have access to clip art, you can use stencils or your imagination.
butcher paper for creating the seaweed
scissors

Introduction:
1. The first step in making your underwater sea creature's family tree is to have the family draw seaweed at various lenghts, paint it green or whatever color they like, brush over the color with glitter paint, have it dry, and the cut it out and hang it on the wall. If you're doing this project without moms involved, it might work out best to have the seaweed done before the group starts.
2. The second step is for each family member to trace their sea creature on a piece of construction paper. Choose colors that are expressive of who they are and feel free to draw or write any shapes, symbols, or words on your sea creature that are significant and meaningful to you. After you have finished coloring or decorating your sea creature, cut it out. Smaller children may need help with this. If there is an infant in your family, a small sea creature can be made for them.
3. The third step is for each family member to decide where they would like to place their sea creatures on the wall with the sea weed.

Purpose:
To create a collage pin representing your vision for your future.

Materials:
3" by 3" card stock
larger card stock (in case anyone wants to collage bigger)
3" by 3" plexiglass
Matte Medium and brush to apply it
magazines and photostock books
scissors
glue sticks
optional: magnets or pin backs and E-6000 glue (supervise the gluing for proper ventilation)
pens and writing paper (teens could also use their journals)
independent project handout (for individual workshop) (click here for handout)

Set Up:
Spread out the supplies on the table. Make sure there is a piece of card stock and a piece of plexiglass at each place. The magazines and photostock books should be spread out so they're accessible to everyone. It may be a good idea to set out some newspaper or paper towel before covering the collages in Matte Medium because it can be messy.

Welcome and Ground Rules:
It can help create a safe environment if you take time to individually welcome each teen, connect with them, and let them know you are glad they are there. Introduce the project and the philosophy of Windows time: "This is a special "window of time" for each of you. For Windows time, we have some Ground Rules to help create respect and safety. Can anyone think of a Ground Rule that would help? Are there any other Ground Rules you'd like to add?" At this time you can mention any pre-established ground rules you have.

Check In:
A good example of an appropriate check-in would be: "Before we start the art, we'll have a check-in circle so everyone has a chance to share their name, how they are feeling today, and any feelings about doing art." This is a time to reassure anyone who's scared of art that it's fine, and to tell anyone who "hates" art that's fine too. Remind them that they don't have to do it, that they can just watch if they want to. When given the freedom, they will probably choose to join in even if they say they're just going to watch. Let them know that it's fine if they don't want to say anything for "check-in", too.

Optional Journaling:
"Write for five minutes about your vision for your future. What comes to mind? Write anything at all that you think of."

Note:
It's helpful to have a sample of how the collage looks with the plexiglass attached.

Project Suggestion:
"This workshop is a chance to create your own vision pin or magnet (see sample). You don't have to know in advance what you want it to look like. You can let it evolve as you go, just like your life evolves as you go. Look through magazines and tear out whatever pictures jump out at you. When you've collected a bunch of them, go ahead and begin to cut out the parts you want to use.
When you start gluing them down, it can help if you glue something over your whole 3" by 3" board. That way, you will have the background you want. If you need to use a bigger board, go ahead, but know there might not be large enough plexiglass for it. When you are finished collaging, you are ready to attach the plexiglass. Remove the brown paper from both sides of the glass. Then cover your collage with a thick layer of Matte Medium. Press the glass onto your collage. Matte Medium will squeeze out the edges as you press. Hold it into position and squeeze the air bubbles out as you press. Try not to get the Matte Medium onto the surface of the glass. When it is complete, take some time to write any words that go with your vision. If there are pins and magnets available you can glue them on the back."

Optional Feedback Exercise:
Ten minutes before the workshop ends, pass out one sheet of paper per person. Ask the teens to write a paragraph about what they learned from the workshop. Ask permission to read these papers so you can learn about the effectiveness of the workshop. You could even take them to copy and return them the next week, so that the teens can add them to their journals.

Closing and Validation:
At the end of the project, a Closing Circle can be a way to give each teen an opportunity to share what she or he has created and talk about what it means to them and how it felt to make it. Just like the check-in circle, give each teen a chance to speak. Validate their courage for opening themselves up to their own creativity and respecting whatever came out.

Row.str_name: Putting myself back together en español—Traducido por Allie Holsen
Row.txt_code:
Objetivo:
Por esciribir y colorear las emociones en una muñeca de papel, las partipantes pueden reflejar de sus emociones corrientes y donde las emociones se radican en el cuerpo. Por escribir y reflejando de sus emociones corrientes y pensar en lo que d esean sentir en futuro, ahondarán el proceso de arreglarse déspues de terminar.

Introducción:
Hoy, vamos a usar las muñcas de papel para que podamos estar en contacto con las emociones las cuales se residen adentro de nuestros cuerpos. Muchas veces pasamos por el día sin parar para darnos cuenta de los sentimientos del cuerpo, reconocer las emociones las que están llegando al superficie y escuchar a lo que nuestro cuerpo nos dice. Cuando nos paramos para escuchar al cuerpo, nos damos cuenta de mantener ciertas emociones en lugares diferentes adentro del cuerpo. Quizás en el pecho, u estomágo, o nuestro corazón. Cada sentimeinto puede tener una intensidad diferente. Algunas veces, no nos damos cuenta de lo que estámos sintiendo y eso está bien.

Reconocer nuestros sentimientos y cómo el cuerpo mantiene estos sentimientos podemos empezar a trabajar con ellos. Empezamos a sentir y procesar cada emoción y eventualmente traformarlas. Algunas veces, podemos sentirnos feliz y triste a la misma vez. Puede confundirnos tener tantas emociones a la misma vez, pero esto es parte de la experiencia de ser humana. Todos tenemos sentimientos, y éstos se cambian cada día con cada experiencia. Por cultivar y amándonos podemos transformar los sentimientos antiguos y empezar de desarrollar los sentimientos que deseamos tener.

Relajación:
Pon música relajante para que empiecen a relarjase.
“Pongáse en una posición cómoda y empiece a sacar el aire. Puede cerrar los ojos o dejarlos abiertos, haz lo que sea lo más cómodo para usted. Pocas veces tomamos tiempo para descansar y concentrarnos en nosotras mismas. Concéntrase en el momento y siente el aire moverse adentro y a fuera. El cuerpo empezará a relajarse. Pon su atención en el aliento, no es necesario cambiar la manera en la que usted respire, embargo necesitas estar consciente de la respiración – exhalando e inhalando. Con cada respiración, permite el cuerpo relajarse. Reconozca el sentimiento del cuerpo. ¿Cuáles son los sentimientos que usted tiene en este momento? Que usted esté consciente de ellos. Si usted se siente sentimientos diferentes, es importante estar consciente de la ubicación de estos sentimientos. Tal vez un cierto sentimiento se resida en el pecho, estómago, o corazón. Mueve el aire a esos lugares y simplemente darse cuenta del cuerpo y cómo se siente. ¿Estás pensando en colores cuando se siente cada emoción? Acepta lo que viene a la superficie con cada respiración. Sigue respirando lentamente, inhala y exhala. Recuérdase que usted está en un lugar seguro y también es seguro experienciar estos sentimientos. Inhala amor y compasión para si misma, es importante que sepas que está rodeada por el amor y apoyo. Cuando ussted esté lista, puede abrir los ojos si están cerrados.”

Primera parte de la creación:
Las mujeres necesitan empezar a reflejar de los sentimientos y colores los cuales llegaron a la mente mientras de la relajación. Pueden escribir adentro de cada trozo de las rompecabezas un sentimiento que tienen en este momento, o han tenido hace algunas horas. Es importante que la líder les motiva pensar en su cuerpo y la ubicación de estos sentimientos para que apunten este sentimiento en el lugar donde se lo encuentra.

Déspues de llenar las rompecabezas con palabras de emociones, pueden colorear cada trozo del puzzle con un color que expresa cada sentimiento.

Escribiendo:
Déspues de crear las muñecas, pueden empezar a escribir sobre el proceso y mirar a todos los sentimientos que llegaron a la mente. Pueden reflejar en la razón por poner ciertas palabras en lugares específicos, el significado de los colores, qué llegó a la mente durante la relajación, cómo se siente mirar a la muñeca que está construida por sus emociones.

Pueden reflejar en llegar a la paz con emociones conflictivas. Por ejemplo, para algunas de las mujeres, todavía se sienten el amor para el abusador pero cada instinto les dice que necesitan salir.

Comparte con ellas que estas muñecas nos ayuda a ver la experiencia de la fragmentación que los seres humanos pueden sentir a veces. Hay un punto en la vida de todo los seres humanos en el que tenemos la experiencia de sentir quebrado y tenemos el reto de descubrir otra vez el sentido de si misma y el sentido del mundo de nuevo. Si se sienten la fragmentación y como si estuvieran quebradas, cómo quieren arreglarse otra vez? Es importante que ellas reflejen de sus próximos pasos. ¿Cuáles son los sentimientos que quieren poner en lugar de los sentimientos que existen? ¿Qué quisieran poner en vez del temor por ejemplo?

¿Cuáles son las cosas las que pueden hacer para arreglarse de nuevo? ¿Cuáles son las cosas las cuales pueden utlizar para capacitarles tener un mejor sentido de estar?

Parte dos: Creación
Déspues de esciribir, las mujeres pueden crear otra muñeca para arreglarse con palabras y colores de amor y cariño. ¡Es importante que la líder les motive para que realicen este paso para empezar a crear esta transformación en sus vidas! Por cultivar y amando sus mismas, pueden transformar los sientimetos del pasado y empezar a tener los sentimientos que ellas desean.

Círculo de clausura:
Al final, darles a las mujeres tiempo para compartir sus muñecas. Si no quieren compartirlas, diles que está bien.

Déspues de que hayan compartido, la líder necesita motivarles para que vean sus fuerzas y la importancia de tener compasión por sus mismas cuando se sienten perdidos en sus emociones. Están haciendo el trabajo aquí y en este momento para arreglarse de nuevo en una manera amorosa. Felicitarles por haciendo tanto trabajo maravilloso y compartir sus sentimientos.
