Row.str_name: Hands of Hope, Hands of Peace
Row.txt_code:
Windows leader Barba ra Sultan of The Lotus Project Los Angeles had her participants choose fabric, trace their hands and cut them out to put on this beautiful quilt. The Lotus Project's art consultant put together most of the quilt but also taught some women how to use a sewing machine to contribute to the finished piece.








Fabric Quilt-'Hands of Hope, Hands of Peace'
Created by women of The Lotus Project

Window's leader Mercedes Brown created the following poem during the Creating a Safe Place workshop.  Feel free to use it as a warm up or part of an introduction when you do the workshop.

A Safe Place
by Mercedes Brown
My place is in the universe, amongst the heaven and the earth.
A place where I can be me, without others complaining how they think I should be.
Where I should be — when I am me.
A safe place to be on earth in this place called me.
A body, a mind and a soul exploring what it means to be free, in this world called me.
My safe place is inside of me.

Micala Gingrich-Gaylord, Children's leader at Youthville in Kansas uses cutouts of shoes instead of the participants feet. Feel free to use her template as a single shoe or trace three together end to toe on a poster board for the past, present and future (see photo below).
Micala's template

Micala Gingrich-Gaylord, Children's leader at Youthville in Kansas uses cutouts of shoes instead of actual shoes. Feel free to use her template as a single shoe or trace three together end to toe on a poster board for the past, present and future (see photo below).
Micala's template

Micala Gingrich-Gaylord, Children's leader at Youthville in Kansas uses cutouts of shoes instead of real shoes. Feel free to use her template as a single shoe or trace three together end to toe on a poster board for the past, present and future (see photo below).
Micala's template

One of Kim's participant's New Highway
Leader Kim Roesch of SafeHouse Denver, Inc. created her own variation of Life Line using the same materials, but added collaging materials.

Kim's version uses a car and road map as a metaphor for each participant on her journey through life. The workshop helps participants identify details about themselves, and their likes and dislikes, by using the symbol of a car traveling on a highway to represent her life. The workshop allows each participant to focus on who she is and where she has been, in order to create a clear picture of where she wants to go and what she has to do to get there.

Warm-up:
Each participant is given a handout with specific questions about the car they will create to represent themselves.  This warm-up allows participants to reflect on who they are and the past events in their lives.

Creation:
Each participant creates a road map of her life to plan for her future. With a handout of descriptions, participants use stop signs, exits, landmarks, road blocks, construction sites and anything they might like to add to represent their life's journey. Participants chart out the goals they want to reach in life, the obstacles they will have to face, how they plan on overcoming them, and achieving what they want in life.

Lupe Diaz & Debi Barrett of WomenShelter of Long Beach had participants write, color and cut the pieces before gluing the pieces on construction paper. They felt that doing this had a demonstrated how difficult it is to put your life back together after a traumatic event, however with great care and patience it can be done.

Row.str_name: Pipe Cleaner Animals By: Devika Shankar
Row.txt_code: Instead of using clay you can have the participants create their Power Animals out of pipe cleaners.  This variation is great for younger children and is much less expensive than using clay!

Speaking in a slow and calm manner say the following:
This art session is a time for you to relax, and to get in touch with yourself, so we're going to begin with a relaxation.  I'd like you to get yourself as comfortable as you can.  You don't have to worry about anything.  This is a time-out from all of the things you have to do, a time-out from your worries & stress, a time just for you. Make sure your comfortable in your seat, make sure your hands and feet are comfortable, put your head down on the table if you like, and if it feels safe for you, let your eyes close.

Now take a deep breath- a very, very deep breath.  As you breathe in, feel your lungs filling with air.  Imagine the air going all the way down into your stomach, and let your stomach stick out as far as it wants to go...  Then let the air go. [exhale]

Continue breathing comfortably.  As you take another breath, imagine the air going all the way into your toes and relaxing them, relax your toes, feet ankles...  Now breathe all the way into your calves, and let them relax...  Now breathe into your thighs, and imagine the air relaxing your legs...  Now notice your stomach.  Is it tense?  As you breathe in again, imagine the air soothing your stomach muscles.  Let any tension flow away with your breath...  Relax the back, the neck, the shoulders, the arms, wrists, hands, forehead, eyebrows, eyes, nose, mouth, and jaw.]

Take one final deepest breath to let your whole body relax, and give yourself a chance to notice how you're feeling right now.  Are you sleepy?  sad?  peaceful?...  When you are ready, you can open your eyes and begin creating the Monster Inside You.

You can also choose to run the complete Clothesline Project Event.

At a Clothesline Project Event, participants may come and create their shirts all day to continuously add to the clothesline. This event is a great educational tool for the community, and a great way to demonstrate how each survivor and victim of abuse is not alone in her story.

The official site of The Clothesline Project offers great tips on how to run the event, and will provide official literature upon request.

For more complete information from The Clothesline Project Click Here!

Simple layering supplies
 
 Sanding of irritant
 
 Layering with words
 
Layering with tissue paper
Materials list:
Plaster pearls
Colored pencils
Sand paper
White tissue paper, sheer ribbon or other translucent materials
1/2 White glue 1/2 Water (instead of Mod Podge)
Paint brushes

Introduction:
Wisdom comes from the difficult things we have experienced. A pearl is a wonderful metaphor for the survivor’s journey. Do you know how a pearl is formed? Basically, it starts with an irritant that enters an oyster; protective layers transform that mollusk and create a pearl. Throughout our lives, we all have challenges and difficulties (irritants). There are lessons to be learned in all these challenges (pearls).

Creation
In this version of the project you will be creating layers on a pearl disk, in 3 stages.

Stages
1. Think about the difficult moments, the hardest points of your life.  Points where your heart was going to break or you felt like your life was going to end. Using colored pencils, utilize colors, shapes, and words to express your difficulties on the disk. It's okay if all you do is scribble, simply do whatever you need to do to release your feelings, your memories of the difficult moments onto your disc. Its okay if you write one word, cover the whole pearl with words, or write no words at all.  There is no right or wrong way to do this stage.

2. Now take sand paper and begin to sand on top of the difficulties you represented on your pearl. Notice what it feels like to touch the surface of your pearl.  What does it feel like to sand and smooth the surface of your pearl?  As you sand, picture time wearing away the difficult memories and negative feelings. Think about how a pearl is created by the mollusk creating layer, upon layer, covering the irritant.  The layers smooth the rough irritant and create a beautiful and strong pearl.

3. If you like, you can add layers, like bandages, to symbolically heal the wounds and reveal the strength and beauty of the pearl.  Picture yourself healing those wounds as you create layers over some or all of the pearl.

Think about how you've healed from your difficulties, what have they taught you and what strength and wisdom have you gained.  Notice that with each layer of your life you grew in new ways that would not have been possible without the struggle.

With your last layer you may choose to add an expression of your wisdom with a color, word, shape, or phrase.

Closing
Allow time for participants to complete the release and evaluation form.
Have a final closing circle for participants to share the advice or wisdom with the group.

Feel free to use the same objective an d warm up for this workshop variation to create fun, whimsical popsicle ornaments! Huge thanks to Children's Windows leader Anna Sanchez for showing us these fun ideas!

Materials:
Popsicle sticks and tongue depressors
Hot glue or tacky glue
Yarn, ribbon or string
Markers or paint pens
Construction paper
Glitter
Gold or silver string, ribbons or pipe cleaners
Paint and/or puffy paint (optional)
Embellishments (optional)

Creation:
Popsicle (craft stick) ornaments are fun and easy.  You will need to use tacky glue or hot glue to adhere all the parts, and decorate!  You can use a silver or gold string for a hanger.

Closing:
It's important to have the women do a closing of the workshop. Have each woman share what their Whimiscal Wooden Ornament means to them and how their inner child feels in this moment.

To end on a hopeful note, remind participants that you hope they will hold onto their ornament as a reminder that they need to care for their inner child and to nurture their joy.  Thank all participants for taking a window of time to create with you.

The Timed Writing can be offered for varying lengths of time, and can be used in groups or by an individual. It's a technique that anyone can use at any time to break through a creative block, explore an idea, or vent an emotion. "I am..." is a very basic, but evocative theme. Other themes to try include "I feel...", "I am proud of...", "I remember...", "I hope...", "I hate...", "Family is...", "Violence is...", etc. Groups of survivors working with The Courage to Heal can use the book's themes as the basis for timed writings. Those in 12 Step Programs could try the 12 steps as themes about which to write.

Timed Writing can stand alone as a creative workshop in itself in conjunction with the Echo Listening. It can also be used as a 10 minute launching point for a visual art-making session. It is wonderful to create drawings, sculpture, and photographs, based on the writings. I often have each woman circle the most positive thing in her writing and the most negative thing (or the most powerful and the most difficult) and then have everyone create a drawing in shapes, lines, and color, of the world of the negative thing and the world of the positive thing. The words and visual imagery often combine to produce an expression more powerful than either one alone.

Other variations of Timed Writing exercises can be found in Natalie Goldberg's Writing Down the Bones.

Another writing technique that I recommend for focused creative writing sessions is Lucia Capacchione's non-dominant hand writing, in which women carry on a dialogue between their two hands. Her powerful non-dominant hand techniques can be found in The Power of Your Other Hand and Recovery of Your Inner Child.
Leaders at Women's Transitional Living Center had participants tear up their aggressive crayon creations to represent that full release of energy and move them into a more "cleared" relaxed mood.

< !--[if gte mso 9]> Objective:
To give the family an opportunity to create gifts that they can make for each other.  To help them notice how giving gifts from the heart can be very special and wonderful gifts.

Materials:
Construction paper
Markers
Scissors (if you have "edger scissors," it's nice to give a special edge to the coupons)
Glue sticks
Glitter, stickers, etc.

Introduction:
Today I want you to think about something that you could create that would make someone in your family happy.  Mothers Day, a Birthday, or any day is an opportunity to give someone you love a special Gift Coupon.  It is one way the family can show how they care about each other.

Opening Circle:
Encourage a sharing of feelings and then have all the families stand/sit in a circle for an appreciation circle.  Ask the family members to hold hands and say something that they appreciate about the family member to their left or right. Continue going around in the circle in this order, so that everyone can share and be appreciated.

Creation:
Every one will have the opportunity to create Gift Coupons for someone in their family.  It could be a hug, an extra chore for the week, a backrub or anything you think the person would enjoy.  The important thing to remember is how good it feels to give of yourself and to receive a heartfelt gift.

Closing Circle:
Share your coupons and something you learned from doing this workshop.  How did it make you to feel to give these Gift Coupons?  How did it feel to receive them?

Additional Information:
You may want to try this workshop during various holidays. Holidays in particular can be a challenging time of the year. Moms and children may be missing their home, old traditions or things from their past.  Ask each person to share the good and bad feelings they've noticed inside them and around them during the holiday.  Whoever doesn't want to share any thoughts can pass.

Note:
In leading this workshop, it is very rewarding to witness the family actually realize that the most important gifts are those they don't need to buy.  It is challenging, but important to help them face the reality that they may not have enough money for many of the things they want (and maybe even some of what they need at times).

Objective:
This project can be thought of as a kind of "mess therapy," in that it can help mothers and children overcome rigid controls on their behavior that were necessary in an atmosphere of constant potential danger, but now serve only to hinder self-expression. Mothers who had limited opportunities to be playful in their own childhoods seem to access a part of themselves that had been severely neglected. In turn, this makes them more emotionally available to their children's needs for creative art expression. This is a very exciting activity for most children, to be allowed to make a big gooey mess and get "dirty" and for the mother to take the lead while practicing a more prominent parental role as the new head of the family. 

Materials:
Gloop:
4 ounce bottle of white glue, at least 2 per family so they can make more than one batch
1 1/2 cups of water
1 teaspoon of borax powder (you can find this among laundry detergents in grocery stores)
Food coloring, a box of four primary colors
Medium mixing bowl, 1 per family
Large spoon, 1 per family
Plastic 2 cup measuring containers, if possible 1 per family
Plastic teaspoon
Paper cups, for carrying Gloop home

Introduction:
Today we are going to make a stretchy, slimy material called Gloop.  Mom will decide how many batches of Gloop will be made and you will work together as a family to create your very own Gloop that you can then play with!  It is important to listen carefully to your mother as she leads you through the creation.

Opening Circle:
Wiggle Down - Sitting down or standing, begin with:
-"Wiggle your toes, deep breath, relax toes."
-"Wiggle your legs, deep breath, relax legs."
-"Wiggle your bottom, deep breath, relax bottom."
-"Wiggle your tummy, deep breath, relax tummy."
-"Wiggle your shoulders, deep breath, relax shoulders."
-"Wiggle your arms & hands, deep breath, relax them."
-"Last now, wiggle your eyes, deep breath, relax eyes."

Creation:
Making Gloop:
Give recipe to mom so she can be the leader of the mess -making.
1. Pour the 4-ounce bottle of white glue into the mixing bowl.
2. Put 1/2 cup of water into the measuring container and pour into mixing bowl with glue. Discuss as a family what color you want to make the gloop (yellow plus red makes orange, red plus blue makes purple, green plus blue makes turquoise, green and red makes brown. Often the children want to mix all four colors, so it is important to worn them that that will create brown).  Then have someone carefully and slowly squeeze either ten drops of one color of five drops of each of the two colors into the bowl with glue and water.  Choose someone else to stir the mixture.
3. Measure 1 cup of water into the measuring container, but do not pour it into the bowl yet. First, choose someone to measure a teaspoon of borax powder, put it into the measuring cup of water, and stir for several minutes until the borax is mostly dissolved.  Give each child in the family a turn to stir.
4. Direct someone to pour the borax mixture into the mixing bowl of colored glue and stir. The Gloop will immediately begin to congeal. There will be extra water in the bowl so it is necessary to scoop the Gloop together with your hands and lift it out of the bowl onto the table. The Gloop will rapidly dry out with handling until it is a nice rubbery texture.  Divide the Gloop into portions for the children to play with.

Suggestions for creative play with Gloop:
Make handprints by pressing palm down, poke holes with fingers, 2 people can tug until it breaks, have dripping contests by holding a piece up high and see which one reaches the table or floor first, press objects into it to make impressions, etc.

Closing Circle:
Have each family member share how it felt to make a mess together! 

Additional Information:
Try this project yourself first so you can get a feel for the materials and the process. This workshop requires that you have easy access to a sink for fetching water and washing out bowls between batches. Be prepared to make a mess!

Objective:
To give the family the opportunity to express loving feelings with words.  Family members create Conversation Heart Shrinky Dinks as a reminder of how special they are and how much others appreciate them.

Materials:
Shrinky Dinks (rough and ready type)
Color pencils
Hole punchers
Ribbon/yarn
Toaster oven
Scissors
Pencil sharpener
Permanent markers
Small paper plates (to collect pencil shavings)
Heart templates (see heart template at back of manual)

Note: Heart shapes should be about 4" (anything smaller than 3" will be difficult to read or see due to shrinkage of material when it cooks)

Introduction:
Today, we are going to celebrate love in a special and magical way.  We will be making Shrinky Dinks to share the nicest feelings and kindest words that make others and us feel good and cared for.   

Opening Circle:
Ask the families to think of the nicest things a friend, family member, teacher or even a stranger has ever said to them.  Discuss how those special compliments made them feel.  Share the magical way that those compliments can give strength and build confidence in one's own self.

Creation:
Today each family member is going to make their very own hearts that send messages of love to those they care about.  They will be making 3 to 6 Shrinky Dink hearts that they will give to each other and that they will receive from their participating family member/members in a gift exchange at the end of the project.
Demonstrate how to color on the Shrinky Dink material, using the rough side to draw on, and how to use darker colors for writing words.  Show a sample of the size they become after they shrink in the oven (they will shrink down to a 3rd of their original size!).

When the hearts are ready for baking, make sure to hole punch them before placing them in the toaster oven.  This way you can add ribbons when they are done, for hanging or wearing the Shrinky Dink hearts. 

After hole punching the hearts, bake the Shrinky Dinks in a preheated toaster oven at 325 degrees (you may want to cut a rectangle shape out of a brown paper grocery bag and turn one corner up to place the Shrinky Dinks on to make it easy to remove from tray or cookie sheet).  Place Shrinky Dink pieces, colored side up, on the brown paper and place the paper on the tray or on the cookie sheet.  Put into preheated oven.  Watch as your Shrinky Dink shrinks!  Bake approximately 1 to 3 minutes.  After pieces lie flat, allow additional 30 seconds of baking time to complete the process.

Remove paper from tray or cookie sheet and lightly press flat with pad of paper or magazine until the pieces have cooled - approximately 15 seconds.

Cut ribbon or yarn to thread through the hearts and knot, then they are ready to wear!

When the Shrinky Dink hearts are done, have each family member exchange their gifts within their family.  Each person will end up with a heart from another family member to remind them of how special and loved they are.

Closing Circle:
Have the family members discuss how it felt to make the special hearts for one another.  And how it felt to receive the positive messages from one another.

Objective:
This simple workshop gives family members a chance to look at what makes them strong and the powerful bond that is created when the family works together as a group.  The finished artwork serves as a symbol of their collective strength and a reminder not to give up, no matter what challenges they face.

Materials:
Poster board, construction paper, or butcher paper (12x18)
Markers or crayons
Writing paper
Ruler

Introduction:
This workshop is about celebrating strength.  We have all, as individuals and as a family, faced obstacles and hard times. Today we are going to look at our own strength and how we, as a family, can grow stronger.   

Opening Circle:
Have the group stand in a circle.  Ask them to hold hands if they feel comfortable.  Go around the circle and have each person share something that makes them strong.  Have them begin by saying "I am strong because..." and then adding a word or phrase about why they are feeling strong. (Example: "I am strong because I am loving.")

Creation:
Each family receives a poster board, a large piece of butcher paper, or construction paper.  Explain that they will be making a puzzle drawing.  On the top of the paper write the words, "I am strong because..."

Instruct the family to talk briefly and then choose a symbol for their family.  Examples include a heart, house, tree, and dove.  Once a symbol is chosen, have one family member draw an outline of that symbol under the title, as large as possible.  Then equally divide the inside of the shape so that each family member has an area.  Write each person's name in their space.

In their area, each person writes all the ways they are strong. They should complete the phrase, "I am strong because..."

(Examples: I am loving, I am a good mom)

You may want to have some writing paper available, in case participants want to write out their words before doing the artwork.

Closing Circle:
The "We Are" circle is a powerful exercise to support individual and group bonding.

Have the group gather in a circle and hold hands. While swinging their arms from front to back, the group says, "We are, We are, We are..." On the third "We are," one person adds a word (for example: powerful). The whole group then says, "We are, We are, We are powerful."

The group continues with "We are, We are, We are..." Then the next person adds a word. Keep going around the circle until everyone has shared.

Additional closing:  Participants can share any insights they have gained from the workshop and how it can support them/their family in the future.

Objective:
To give family members an opportunity to express what love means to them; to explore how sharing love can support them, as well as spread love throughout the family.  This activity supports participants in listening from their hearts, noticing the feelings that are present when they give and receive love, and seeing how family members are uplifted/affected by it.

Materials:
People shapes
Wiggly eyes
Yarn
Foam heart shapes  
Construction paper, decorative paper or fabric
Additional supplies (i.e. buttons, ribbon)
Glitter glue
CrayPas
Markers
Scissors
Glue sticks
Butcher paper or poster board (if applicable: see page two)

Introduction:
Today we are going to talk about love.  There are many ways to express love.  Love can mean different things to different people.  It can even mean different things at different times, like when we're happy and when we're mad.  Have you ever been mad at someone you love?  Does it mean you don't love them? Of course not, sometimes we feel angry at those we love.

Opening Circle:
You can do a closed eye exercise to support participants in connecting with their loving feelings inside.  When they open their eyes, you can ask one or more of the following questions and encourage each person to share from their hearts (answers can be one or two words).

"What/who do you love?" - "my mom" or "ice cream"
"How do you show love?" - "I smile" or "I give my sister a hug"
"How do you give love?" - "I help with chores" or "I say I love you"

Creation:
Have each family member choose one of the "people shapes" to represent themselves; as well as a foam heart.

On the foam heart:  encourage participants to write words, thoughts, and feelings that touch them; expressing the love they feel in their own hearts.

Each person will then personalize their people shape, by adding yarn for hair, googly eyes, etc.  They can use the colored or decorative paper to make clothes and accessories (hat, shoes, etc), and then add buttons or bows.

The final step is to glue their heart on their person they have created.

When the "dolls" are finished, they can punch a hole in each hand and use yarn to connect each "doll" to the others and create a family chain.

Or, if space and time allows, each family can create an environment for their "dolls."  They can envision what they want their world/future to look like (a house, a pet, etc.), and draw it on large butcher paper or poster board.  They can use the markers and craypas.

Closing Circle:
Ask each person to share their "people" art, and the words they wrote about love.  You can also talk about the ways love can touch each other.  Some questions to ask: How does it make you feel to express the love that is in your heart?  How can giving and receiving love support you and your family?

Objective:
To give family members an opportunity to express what love means to them; to explore how sharing love can support them, as well as spread love throughout the family.  This activity supports participants in listening from their hearts, noticing the feelings that are present when they give and receive love, and seeing how family members are uplifted/affected by it.

Or, if space and time allows, each family can create an environment for their "dolls."  They can envision what they want their world/future to look like (a house, a pet, etc.), and draw it on large butcher paper or poster board.  They can use the markers and craypas.

Objective:
This simple workshop gives family members a chance to look at what makes them strong and the powerful bond that is created when the family works together as a group.  The finished artwork serves as a symbol of their collective strength and a reminder not to g ive up, no matter what challenges they face.

Markers or crayons
Writing paper
Ruler

Introduction:
This workshop is about celebrating strength.  We have all, as individuals and as a family, faced obstacles and hard times. Today we are going to look at our own strength and how we, as a family, can grow stronger.   

Opening Circle:
Have the group stand in a circle.  Ask them to hold hands if they feel comfortable.  Go around the circle and have each person share something that makes them strong.  Have them begin by saying "I am strong because..." and then adding a word or phrase about why they are feeling strong. (Example: "I am strong because I am loving.")

Creation:
Each family receives a poster board, a large piece of butcher paper, or construction paper.  Explain that they will be making a puzzle drawing.  On the top of the paper write the words, "I am strong because..."

Instruct the family to talk briefly and then choose a symbol for their family.  Examples include a heart, house, tree, and dove.  Once a symbol is chosen, have one family member draw an outline of that symbol under the title, as large as possible.  Then equally divide the inside of the shape so that each family member has an area.  Write each person's name in their space.

In their area, each person writes all the ways they are strong. They should complete the phrase, "I am strong because..."

(Examples: I am loving, I am a good mom)

You may want to have some writing paper available, in case participants want to write out their words before doing the artwork.

Closing Circle:
The "We Are" circle is a powerful exercise to support individual and group bonding.

Have the group gather in a circle and hold hands. While swinging their arms from front to back, the group says, "We are, We are, We are..." On the third "We are," one person adds a word (for example: powerful). The whole group then says, "We are, We are, We are powerful."

The group continues with "We are, We are, We are..." Then the next person adds a word. Keep going around the circle until everyone has shared.

Additional closing:  Participants can share any insights they have gained from the workshop and how it can support them/their family in the future.

Row.str_name: Family Windows: Family Coat of Arms
Row.txt_code:
Objective:
To provide each member of the family with an opportunity to come together and create a banner with a special symbol to represent their family.  This allows families to reflect on and explore how they are unique and special and how this makes them strong.

Materials:
Coat of Arms templates for each family
Markers
Pencils
Colored pencils
Crayons
Erasers
Scissors
Felt
Fabric markers
Fabric glue
Square piece of cotton cloth or butcher paper to create banner
Optional: Family picture, glitter glue, beads, feathers and yarn

Introduction:
Today, you will be creating a Coat of Arms Family Banner to represent your family.  Coat of Arms were used many years ago by families to represent what they stand for, what is important to them, where they are from, and who they are.  These Coat of Arms were passed down through generations of families.  Some people still have their family's Coat of Arms today.  Native American tribes also use symbols and banners to represent their different tribes and families.  Together as a family you are going to make your own Coat of Arms Family Banner to tell others about your family and why you are strong.

Opening Circle:
Before you begin to create, have the family gather around in a circle.  Together begin to think of what makes you special and what makes you strong.  What are some symbols that you would use to represent your family?  Maybe each family member would be a different symbol.  What are your favorite colors?  How would you describe yourself?

Think about these things as a family and give everyone a turn to share their ideas.

Creation:
The family can decide whether to create one Coat of Arms together, or to have each family member create their own Coat of Arms, to be displayed on the Family Banner.  Remember to give family members a chance to share their ideas and be a part of the creation.  The family can use the Coat of Arms templates provided as a basis for their creation, or create straight from their imagination.  

Begin by dividing the Coat of Arms into 4 sections.  Then use markers, crayons, or colored pencils to draw the following:

In the upper left box:  Pick and draw an animal to represent your family (examples:  lion, bear, butterfly, eagle, horse, dragon, fish, or a combination of a few animals).

In the upper right box: Draw your family's favorite thing to do together.  An activity that makes your family happy, that makes you feel special.

In the lower left box: Draw people who you consider your family (example: this could include grandparents, cousins, etc.).  If you have a photo of your family, you can include that here.

In the lower right box: Draw what keeps you and your family safe.  Draw people, places, or things that help your family stay safe and feel strong.

Once the Coat of Arms is finished cut it out.  Decide as a family what shape you want your banner to be and how you might hang it in your home.  Once you have cut your banner into the desired shape, glue the Coat of Arms onto the banner and add any additional decorations with glitter glue, beads, feathers and yarn to make it just as unique and special as your family.

When your banner is complete think of a "motto" for your family - 3 words to describe your family.  You may even write this on you banner to be the final touch!

Closing Circle:
Have each person share their new Coat of Arms Family Banner with the group.  Point out the uniqueness in each and how special the family is.  These Coat of Arms Family Banners are a powerful symbol of how strong and special each family is!

Objective:
To provide an opportunity to reflect on the positive things the family shares.  To give family members a sense of pride and encouragement, so that they may acknowledge their strengths and celebrate their blessings.

Materials:
Large butcher paper
Four-leaf clovers (pre-cut out of construction paper, see template at back of manual)
Crayons
Markers
Glue
Optional: green and/or gold glitter and lamination sheets

Introduction:
A four-leaf clover is a symbol of good luck.  According to legend, each leaflet represents something: the first is for hope, the second is for faith, the third is for love, and the fourth is for luck.  Today we're going to reflect on the good fortunes you have experienced as a family.  Think about the positive things you have shared (i.e. what you are most proud of, what you have learned from each other, how you have supported each other, etc).

Opening Circle:
Ask each person to share one to three things about their family that they appreciate/are proud of.

Creation:
There are two steps in this workshop.  First, families will work as a group to create a family portrait.  On a large piece of butcher paper, each person draws herself/himself.  Second, family members write their good fortunes on four-leaf clovers. These can be made beforehand out of construction paper.  When finished, the shapes can be glued around the family portrait.

Closing Circle:
Families can share their portraits and good fortunes.  How do these good fortunes make each person feel?  Look at ways this can support them in their lives, and share any insights they have gained that can help them in creating a healthy future.

Objective:
To provide families an opportunity to decorate the doors of their residence, creating a unique and fun environment that celebrates a special occasion, holiday, or season.

Materials:
Butcher paper
Construction paper
Drawing materials and/or paint
Scissors
Novelty trim (such as stickers, ribbons, etc.)

Introduction:
We are going to have the chance to decorate our doors.  The doors can reflect any occasion like a birthday, holiday or season. 

Opening Circle:
Think about the statement you would like your door to make.

Make a family decision about what theme the door should be, for example if it is in December you can make the door look like a ginger bread house or a fireplace with stockings hanging.  If it is your birthday month you can decorate the door to look like a giant cake, or if it is the start of the Spring season you can do a garden with lots of beautiful flowers.  Perhaps each family would like to share what theme they have decided upon.

Creation:
You can cover the entire door with butcher paper or just cover sections of it.  Before you begin decorating, discuss what your theme looks like.  You might want to do a simple sketch of your plan.  Each family member can be assigned to a different part of the door design deciding if you want to paint or cut out your decorations.  You might want to create a large collage, anything is possible - it is your door!

Closing Circle:
Once the door is complete, ask the families to discuss why they choose the theme and what it felt like to complete the task together.

Note: You may want to make this project monthly or seasonal, as a door-decorating contest, and families can plan ahead!

Objective:
The objective of Pass the Painting is to build teamwork.  The end result can serve as a reflection of the family dynamic and be a strong point for meaningful conversation about trust respect and family harmony.

Materials:
Large poster board or butcher paper
Paintbrushes
Various types of paint (acrylic, puff paints, glitter paint, tempera)
Containers for water
Sponges, markers (optional)

Introduction:
Today I want you to think about how it feels to share with other members of your family.  Think about if it is easy, difficult, fun, annoying etc.  The project we are going to do is called "Pass the Painting."  During this project each of you will get a chance to work together sharing space on the same piece of paper.

The important thing to remember is that you do not try to control the end product.  This is a group effort, and you are to trust that something beautiful will come out in the end.  Remember that you don't have to worry about this looking like anything when it is finished.  Towards the end you will try to fill your whole paper.  Remember there is no wrong way to draw your part.

Opening Circle:
Let's review some of the guidelines for Pass the Painting:
We will share the supplies
We will wait for our turn
We are not going to write words on the paper
We may not overlap or cover up another person's work
We will keep circling until we cover the whole paper or all decide when the artwork is complete.

Creation:
Each group will have one person start by making a mark or shape on the page.  The only rule is that they not cover up any mark that others have made or change the colors that the others have used.

Support participants through the process by reminding them this is about teamwork and sharing ideas supportively.  If the group ends early you can have some paper ready so the participants can journal about the experience and how it felt to share the creativity.

Closing Circle:
It is important that each person get a chance to share about how this process made them feel and what things came up for them while doing the painting.  How did they overcome those feelings or deal with them?  In the end make a statement about how important teamwork can be as well as how support can be helpful to smooth out any feeling that can arise during the process.  The families will notice how they had to respect the boundaries of the other family members as well as trust that their work will be preserved, learning that each part of the work is equally important.

< !--[if gte mso 9]> Objective:
To help families voice feelings, emotions, fears and inner thoughts; as well as empower each family member to give them new confidence, freedom and joy through puppetry.

Materials:
Yarn
Feathers
Buttons
Fabric scraps
Glue and/or glue gun
Sequins
Pom poms
Pipe cleaners
Markers
Wood pieces
Wooden spoons and/or socks (depending on which type of puppets you are making)

Introduction:
You can start by talking about puppets; ask the families if they have ever seen a puppet maybe even a shadow puppet.  You can explain that a puppet is any object that appears to be alive when it is set in motion by a human hand.  A puppet can have its own personality, voice and even its own language.  Puppets come alive, and as they do, the participants can discover a new way to be expressive.

Opening Circle:
Ask each family member to select a sock out of a pile, and then put that sock on their hand.  Ask each person to name the "sock" and say how the sock is feeling - shy, excited, scared, angry, happy, etc.  Then you can begin to decorate.  The puppet's name and voice may change as the personality evolves.

Creation:
You may want to begin with the sock puppet, as it is the easiest for all ages to make and operate.  Show how when you put your hand in the sock, with the thumb in the heel and your fingers in the toe section - you have the beginnings of a puppet already! Next is adding eyes, mouth, hair and any accessories like glasses, hats, etc.

You can practice talking by having the puppet count to 10 - experimenting with the different ways the mouth moves for each number.  As you feel more comfortable you can enhance the sock puppets with things like construction paper beaks for birds, floppy felt or cloth ears for dogs, a cut paper cup to extend a nose of a dragon or insert red fabric or paper to make a large mouth (you can even add teeth)!  An old sock can easily be converted into a simple or complex puppet!

Spoon puppets can also be made with anything with a long thin handle - wooden mixing spoons, wire whisks, feather dusters or paintbrushes.  The bowl of the spoon makes a perfect head, gluing a yarn wig makes the hair and you can use pipe cleaners for the arms.  Dress the spoon with a piece of fabric with a hole cut in the middle for the head.  As the puppet develops a personality you can build a story about who she/he is and where she/he came from!

Closing Circle:
Ask each participant to have their puppet introduce him/herself using the voice of the puppet stating something about themselves like telling a story, talking about a hobby or a made-up adventure the puppet has had.  You can have the family make up an adventure with each puppet as a character in the story.

Additional Information:
You may even want to plan for a puppet show, making up a story with all the characters.  Performing in a show can be great fun.  The possibilities are endless!!

Be prepared, often children will act out their own story or secrets - pretending it to be the puppet's story.  The puppet can give a voice to pain, it can empower shy children and it can be a great tool to nurture creativity.  Have fun!

Objective:
To give the family an opportunity to reflect on their journey through domestic violence and to think about their wishes for the future, as they create collages of the past, present and future.

 

Materials:
5x7 Card stock
Collage materials (magazines, photo stock books)
8x10 mat frames
Glue sticks
White glue
Hole puncher or poking tools
Ribbon
Small decorations such as glitter, sequins and stickers

Introduction:
Today we are going to create 3 collages.  The first will tell the story of your family life before you came to the shelter, the second will be about your life since you came to the shelter, and the third will show what you hope your life will be like in the future.  I hope by the end you will see how your journey has made you stronger and that it will give you hope for the future.

We are going to take 25 minutes for each collage.

Opening Circle:
Starting with the children, ask if it would be okay to have a check-in circle where everyone shares their feelings about their life before coming to the shelter.  If they don't feel like talking too much about it, you could start with a simple one-word circle about how they are feeling right now.  Ask them to discuss things they miss from their past and reasons they're glad they have made changes in their present situation.

Creation:
The first collage we will be creating is a collage of our lives before we came to the shelter.  I want you to look through magazines and cut out words and images that represent what your lives were like before you came to the shelter.  We will take about 10 minutes to pick your images and words and I will let you know when it's time to glue.

Turn on light music and remind them that they have 25 minutes to create.  After 15 minutes, let the family know that they have a 10 more minutes and that they should start to glue their images.  Reassure them that it's okay if images overlap.  Check with each other to make sure that it is okay to cover any part of another's images.

Repeat the process for the present.  Have a quick one-word circle to check in on how they are feeling.  They may be feeling pretty low at this point.  Encourage them to notice how strong and brave they are to take these steps. 

Before getting started on the third collage, take some cleansing breaths.  Ask them to take a few breaths as they envision their future.  Be sure to encourage the family to include all their greatest hopes and wildest dreams for their family once they leave the shelter.

Once all three collages are complete have the families decorate their creations and attach them together by using ribbon.

Closing Circle:
Have the mom take notes about how it felt for each person to create each collage. Mom can read back to her children what she thinks they said, and then have each mom share with the group.

If time allows, you could have a final circle starting with the children, and have each person share how it felt to create the series of collages.

Row.str_name: Family Windows: Creating a Safe Home
Row.txt_code:
< !--[if gte mso 9]> Objective:
Gives the family an opportunity to reflect on what a safe home looks like, and to see themselves in a more peaceful future by creating a quilt about their future for their new home.

Materials:
8" X 8" square pieces of fabric (at least one per person)
Fabric paint
Glitter
Buttons
Feathers
Rhinestones
Scissors
Sewing machine
Needle and thread
Fabric marker
Glue
Cray-pas
Paper to cover tables

Introduction:
Today we will be creating a quilt of our own home in the future.  Each family member will be given a square of fabric, and they will design a window that looks into their safe home.  What does safety mean to you?  How does it make you feel?  What does it look like?

Opening Circle:
Ask the family to close their eyes and take 3 deep breaths and begin the following visualization:

"Think of something quiet: you might be floating on a cloud, or swimming in the sea, or walking in a beautiful forest, or lying on bunches of soft pillows, or moving your body.  Choose any special place where you feel quiet and safe.  Think about what the place looks like.  What does it smell like?  Who is there?  What does it feel like?  Is it a place you have never seen before?  Is it in your imagination?  It can be special and safe just for you.  You make it safe, you make all the magic and power in this safe place."

When you are ready, open your eyes if you closed them and quietly go to the table, and make your safe place picture on your piece of fabric.

Creation:
Each family member will design a window or windows of their safe home in the future.  It can be anything that represents safety.  Once they are dry, attach the squares to a quilt, blanket or sheet by either sewing them with a needle and thread or gluing them together.

Closing Circle:
Starting with the children, have each person share their square or squares one at a time.

Additional Information:
You may want to contact a local Quilting group, Church group, or Community Center to come to the shelter and show the family how to sew a quilt.

This project can be wonderful for an exhibit!

< !--[if gte mso 9]> Objective:
To give family members an opportunity to explore their wishes for the holidays and help create positive feelings as they look forward to having a special holiday season.

Materials:
For tree: construction paper, butcher paper or poster board.

For ornaments: different color construction paper (shapes can be pre-cut: stars, circles, diamonds, ovals, driedeles, etc)
Glue sticks
Markers
Color pencils
Yarn or ribbon
Glitter sticks
Scissors 

Introduction:
You can begin by reading any holiday book.  For example one about: Kwanza, Hanukah, Christmas - anything that seems appropriate to the group.  Or have the families each read separately what they considered appropriate to their family.
 
Opening Circle:
Have the families sit in a circle, close their eyes and remember their favorite holiday memories (what did it smell like, how did it look, was there a tree, were there lights, what kind of food was there?).  Ask: if they could make 3 wishes what would they be (i.e. have a house, have toys, etc.).  Try to encourage the family to be creative with their wishes.

Creation:
This workshop has two steps.

The first step is to make a large holiday tree.  If you have enough space, you can make a "group" tree out of butcher-block paper (or piece together construction paper).  If not, each family can create their own tree on poster board.  You can use glitter to add sparkle.  You can also add presents at the bottom (cut paper squares, decorated with glitter, yarn or ribbon).

The second step is to make the decorations.  On the shapes, ask the family members to write their wishes for the holidays.

Next, they can decorate them with glitter, ribbons, etc.  When finished, glue the decorations on the holiday tree.

Closing Circle:
Each person shares his or her wishes for the holidays.  They can be wishes for themselves or for their family.

Objective:
To give families an opportunity to begin to heal their past and transform their future by creating banners that incorporate their own hands and feet.  By reflecting on their footsteps and joining their hands together, families can notice their combined strength and inspire the community to reach for a violence free future.

Materials: 
Glue sticks
Scissors
Magazines
Markers
Construction paper
Relaxing music
Large piece of butcher paper
Laminating sheets and laminator (optional)

Introduction:
Today, each member in the family will have the opportunity to create a collage that validates their unique journey through domestic violence using the outline of their own feet.  Throughout our life it is our feet that carry us from one experience to the next.  When we leave abusive situations our feet carry us out and those same feet can carry us into a new life free from violence.  As the head of the family, it is the mom that leads her children in their journey.  As she takes each step, the children follow her direction, each person moving towards healing their past and transforming their future.

Opening Circle:
Let's begin by taking a few deep breaths and feeling our feet on the ground.  Our feet are strong and carry us through each day in our life.  Feel your feet on the floor and notice their strength. Where have they carried you in your journey through domestic violence?  What images, words, and colors come to mind?  Where would you like your feet to carry you now?  What would a life free from violence look like?  Where would you like to lead your family in the future?  How would you like to walk together as you transform your future?

Creation:
Play relaxing music as the family creates their feet.

Each family member will begin by tracing the outline of their feet on a piece of construction paper.  Once this is done, cut out the footprints so that they are ready to be collaged on.  One footprint will become a collage about your past, while the other footprint will become a collage about your future.

Choose magazine images that speak to you, about your experiences of the past, as well as your wishes and dreams for the future.  Children may want to use markers to color their images instead, or can do a combination of coloring and collaging.  Cover the whole foot in layers of collaged or drawn images and words, creating on just one side of the foot.

When your collaged feet are done, think about what words you may want to go with each footprint.  These words can be added to the banner later, to tell the story of where your feet have been and where they want to go.  Next, laminate the footprints so that they are ready to be put on the banner. 

All of the families in the shelter can then add their footprints on one large banner.  Place each footprint on the banner, one in front of the other, with the future footprint leading the way.  Each family can have a section of the banner with the mother's footprints leading the way for her children's footprints, creating a path of feet as the mother leads her family towards a future free of violence.  Have fun decorating the banner!

If there is a baby in the family, paint their feet and add their footprints to the banner too! 

Closing Circle:
Encourage each family to share their footprints, and to notice how together these footprints will become footsteps from the family's past into their future.  Thank each of them for sharing their journey, hopes, and dreams, and for creating together.

If they wish, they can even hang their banner within their shelter or community to send a powerful message to the greater community!

Row.str_name: Family Windows: Let's Join Hands Together to Stop the Violence
Row.txt_code:
Materials:
White poster paper or a large piece of butcher paper
Washable paint
Paper plates
Brushes
Paper towels
Magic markers
Pastels
Colored construction paper

Introduction:
Today, you will work together as a family to create a banner to inspire each other and the greater community to join hands together to stop the violence.  Each family will include their handprint with a message of their own for a violence free future, while also reflecting on what they can do to make the community a better place. 

Opening Circle:
Begin by gathering around in a circle and holding hands.  Notice how hands can be a symbol of togetherness and unity.  Let's go around in a circle and share our ideas of what we can each do to make the community a better place.  It could be something as simple as giving a hug to your mom, being caring and loving to family and friends, or even picking up trash at the beach.  Everyone's ideas are important and make a difference!

Creation:
Place white poster board sheets together or use a large sheet of butcher paper to create a long banner.  Decide on a slogan for the banner, such as "Let's Join Hands Together to Stop the Violence."  Then cut out multi-colored paper letters to spell out your slogan, and decide where to place it on the banner.

Next mix paint colors on paper plates, so you have various colors to choose from.  Have each family member pick colors together and take turns dipping their hands in the paint, or have mothers and their children paint each other's hands and fingers. 

Have fun helping each other decide where to place your handprints on the banner.  Enjoy the process, even if it is messy!

While the handprints dry, talk about your ideas of how to create a better, safer, violence free community.  After the handprints are dry have each family member write their ideas inside of their handprint on the banner.  If the children are young, mothers can help write their ideas down for them, using the child's words.

Closing Circle:
Have everyone join together and share what they created and how it felt to work together.  Encourage everyone to notice how empowering it is when we join our voices and hands together!

Additional Information:
Both banners, option 1 and 2, can be created separately or combined.  Each banner creates a strong visual statement that unites the families and sends a powerful message to the greater community.  Final banners can be hung in the shelter or community to help raise awareness and inspire others!

Janet Chaize of Alternatives to Battered Women shared a powerful warm-up that she used for this workshop. Janet felt like this warm-up really helped to open up the group and get people participating.

Each woman was given an envelope with a different statement inside. The statements were related to a strength, for example "I have overcome... because...". Each woman went around the circle, pulled out their statement and read it, filling in the blanks.

Eva Fiallos-Diaz of Refuge House in Ft Lauderdale, FL combined this workshop with Earth Day and made easy eco-friendly beads! However, she did note, this workshop is time-consuming. Eva suggests taking 3 sessions or more, this first session participants will create the beads from the pulp.

Recipe for Paper Pulp
newspaper shreds
wallpaper paste or glue
hot water

Combine newspaper shreds and hot water in a bowl and let them soak thoroughly for about 1 hour. Next, squeeze excess water out of the newspaper and mix it with the wallpaper paste or glue. Add enough paste to thicken the paper mache to the consistency of modeling clay.

Hint: Paper mache shrinks as it dries.

Row.str_name: Advanced Scupley Techniques - Age Range 13 and up
Row.txt_code:
Project Explanation:
Today we’re going to create a “Pay Attention to ME” person.  We’re going to use a technique called “cane work.”  This is the same technique that is used to do glass beadwork in Italy.  Th e first step is to make the “cane”  which will become the foundation of our creation. A cane is a cylinder of clay that has a design running through the middle of it.  When the cane is sliced at any point, the design will be revealed.


 
 Sculpey cane with straight seam
 
In this workshop, we will be using a “jelly roll” design for the cane. (When sliced, it will resemble an old-fashioned cake that is rolled with jelly in the middle of it). The “jelly roll” is one of the simplest cane designs; there are many other beautiful cane designs that can be made!

Creation:
Look back at your journaling exercise and reflect on the needs you identified.  Decide what you want your clay person to be.  You can choose to represent one aspect of your needs (physical, spiritual or emotional), or focus on one specific need (such as eight hours of sleep).  Or, your clay person can be a reminder to pay attention to all of your needs!

First, we will need to condition the clay.  When you first open the package of Sculpey, the clay will feel stiff and hard.  In order to soften and easily work with it, you will need to warm it up first.  We will be each using the band-aid color and two contrasting colors that you can select.

Starting with the band-aid colored clay, you can begin to manipulate and play with it.  Break it apart into smaller pieces.  Squeeze it.  Stretch it.  As you continue handling it, you’ll start to feel it getting softer.  Keep working with it, rolling it, kneading it and stretching it.  Join the pieces back together.  When it’s soft, roll it up into a ball.  Once the band-aid color is softened and made into a 2" ball, do the same with the 2 contrasting colors.  You will end up with 3 balls of clay.

Note: Some colors (especially red) may bleed onto your hands.  Don’t worry. You can use a handiwipe to clean your hands when you’re done.

Perspective reminder: After each step, remind participants that this is their window of time to notice and respect their needs.

Tell your group that you will be walking them through the entire creation process. There are 17 steps to creating your Pay Attention to ME person and it is made up of 3 parts: a head, arms (upper body), and legs (lower body).  Making the “jelly roll” cane is the most important step; it will become the foundation of your whole project!  Are you ready to start making your “jelly roll” cane?

Making the “Jelly Roll” Cane:
For this part you will be using the two contrasting colored balls you made earlier. Put the band-aid colored ball aside to rest, as we will be using it later (in Step 6).

  
Rolling out the layers of contrasting
colors for the cane 
 
Step 1: After you condition each color, you’ll need to turn each one into a rectangular sheet.  Start with the first color.  Using all the clay, begin to pinch and pull your shape into a rough rectangular slab.  You can flatten it more by using your rolling pin.  You’re going to end up with a shape that is 3” wide by 5” long.  It doesn’t have to be exact.  There are rulers on the table if you want to measure it.  You can also use the side of the blade to “push in” and straighten the sides.  As you finish with one of the colors, do the same with the other one.  Both rectangles should end up being the same size.

  
Slicing the edge at a slant for easier rolling
to create the cane
 
  
 Rolling the Sculpey
 
  
 Stretching the cane to 12 inches
 
  
 Slicing the cane
 
  
Make small band-aid color balls and
thinly slice the cane		 
  
 Cover the ball with the slices 
  
 Roll the ball so it is seamless 
  
 Cut the cane in 2" pieces and share colors
 
  
 Explore by mixing colors
 
Step 2: Layer one colored rectangle on top of the other one.  Once you’ve done this, gently press them together so there are no air bubbles.  On one side of the rectangles, use your blade to create a slanted edge. This will make it easier to roll the clay.

Step 3: Starting with the slanted side, gently roll one color inside the other one.

Step 4: Reduce the cane in size by rolling it between the palms of both hands and the work surface (pressing gently to make it smaller).  Make sure to distribute the pressure evenly along the cane.  You can also gently pull at both ends to stretch it.  Your goal is to end up with a cane that is approximately 12” in length.  Make certain that the seam created, from the roll, is straight. Don’t worry if the ends get distorted. 

Step 5: Once your cane is approximately 12” long, take your blade and make a cut/slice in the middle.  You can now see your jelly roll!  Put both pieces aside (you will use them in Steps 7 & 10).

Tips for Cutting/Slicing
Use a sharp knife/blade to cut your cane, so the shape will become less distorted. Getting a nice clay cane slice can sometimes be trickier than it looks, especially if the clay is too soft.  Clay is easier to slice when it is on the cooler side.  If you have time (and a refrigerator close by), you can refrigerate it for 5 to 10 minutes to firm up.  If not, don’t worry; you’ll still achieve a beautiful effect!

If the cane is soft, roll it at the same time you are cutting it.  This will help to keep it round, and not flatten.
 
Step 6: Take the band-aid colored ball you made earlier.  This will be used to make the insides of the beads.  Cut it in quarters, you will end up with 4 pieces.  Roll each piece into a ball.

Step 7: Next take one half of the cane you cut in Step 5 (6-inch length).  We’re going to cut off a dozen thin slices (approx. 1/8” thick). You can make more if needed later.  The slices may come out a little more oval than round, that’s okay!

Step 8: Next you’re going to cover one of the band-aid color balls (made in Step 6) with the thin slices you just cut.  Place the slices next to each other, with all of the edges touching (like putting pieces of a puzzle together).  Cover the whole ball with the tiny slices.  If you need more slices, cut them off the cane (only cut the amount you need).  Put the leftover cane aside - it can be used later to make beautiful beads!

Step 9: After the ball is completely covered, roll it gently in the palms of your hands to blend the design together.  As you continue to roll it, you’ll see that all the seams will disappear.  That is what you want to achieve.  If any of the band-aid color is exposed, you can move around the slices around to cover it.

Step 10: Take the other half of the cane you cut in Step 5 (6-inch length).  We’re now going to make the cane a little thinner for another design variation.  We’re going to stretch this 6-inch piece into approx. 14 inches (to compensate for the distorted ends).  Just as you did in Step 4, (keeping the seam straight), you can gently pul the ends.

Step 11: From the cane you just made, cut off approximately 1 inch to remove the distorted end.  If you don’t see the jelly roll, cut off another 1/2 inch.  Now we’re going to share your colors with other participants in the workshop.  Cut 2” pieces of your cane, and give each person a piece.  You’ll still have the original color you chose; now you’ll also have other colors to work with! 

Step 12: You are now going to cover 2 more band-aid colored balls (from Step 6) with tiny slices.  (Note: we will only be using 3 “covered” balls for our clay person: the 2 made here, and the one made in Steps 8 & 9). You will have one band-aid ball left over.

You have many options. You can use the same colored cane for each ball (your original color or a color you just received).  Or you can mix and match colors.  You can also mix the large and small designs.  You can make all 3 balls the same, or all different - whatever you like!  Tell participants to choose the colors/designs that nurture their needs!

To cover the balls, use the technique in Steps 8 and 9.

Row.str_name: My Safe Place Quilt by Angelica Costello
Row.txt_code:
Materials:
Pencil
Markers
Material cut into squares (or Button & Loop quilt fabric squares from Discount School Supply)
Paint (tempera and/or watercolor)
Paint brushes
Cups

Creation:
Have the participants sketch a drawing of their safe place with pencil on a piece of paper, then transfer it on the square material (or have them draw directly on the square). Use markers and/or paint to create on the squares. If you want to be able to wash the quilt use fabric paint and markers on the squares.  Ask for permission to keep their piece to create a quilt.  After you have enough squares, give them to a quilter to make the quilt.  If you use the Button & Loop fabric squares you can bypass the sewing and simply button the squares together.

Row.str_name: Fear Ghost Buster using balloons by Flor Martinez
Row.txt_code:
Use the same process for the workshop, simply modify the materials.  After creating, the children can pop the balloons as another way to symbolize conquering their fears.

Materials:
Replace styrofoam balls with balloons
Helium for balloons (optional)
Replace white fabric with white trash bags

Row.str_name: I Can:Requiem for I Can't - Children's Version
Row.txt_code:
Note: This variation was developed for children ages 12 and under but can be used with older clients.
 
Shredded I Cant's

  
Objective:
This workshop is about getting rid of the things we think we can't do and realize that we can! 
  
 
 Completed I Can Shrinky Dink

Materials:
White card stock for I Can't journaling
Pens/Multi-colored pens (optional)
Colored paper for I Can statements
Shrinky Dink paper
Shrinky templates
Colored pencils
Hole punch
Blunt Scissors
Toaster oven
Ribbon
Beads
Music (suggested: Baby Blue by Carlos Reynosa for I Can't journaling and Heavenly for I Can statement and shrinky creation)
Timer
2012 Art/Photography Release forms for parent to complete.

Timeframe: 1 hour 30 minutes
Opening Circle: 5 min
Intro: 5 min
Writing/Drawing: 10 min
Sharing & Tearing: 20 min
I Can Statement Creation: 15 min
Shrinky Creation: 20 min
Closing: 15 min

Opening Circle:
Go around the room and have each child share their name and how they're feeling right now.

Introduction:
Explain to the children that some of what they will be creating today will be turned in and used in an art exhibit. Explain to them that an exhibit is a collection of art that other people can see and learn from. 

This workshop is about getting rid of the things we think we can't do and realize that we can!  Confronting the things we feel we cannot do in our lives is the first step towards recognizing that we can. By allowing ourselves to go through this process and sharing it through the exhibit, we are coming together to collectively let go of our I Cant's and celebrate our I Cans. 

We will begin by writing and drawing our I Cant's and then we will destroy them! 
Then, we will focus on all of the things we can do. Finally you will create an I Can shrinky dink to remind you that anything possible!

  
 
Completed I Can shrinky

  
Writing I Can'ts:
We are going to begin by taking 5-10 minutes to write about or draw a picture of anything or things that you think you can't do. You can use a pen or pencils to write your I cant's or draw pictures.Keep in mind that there is no right or wrong way to do this exercise.

Give a piece of white card stock paper to each child.  You can write sentences, words, lists or draw symbols, shapes. The most important thing is that you that you keep writing or creating for the whole ten minutes. Don't worry about spelling or grammar.  What you write is just for you and does not have to make sense to anyone but you!

You can begin by writing the words "I Can't" on the top of your paper.  Try to keep writing until time is up.  Note: If you have a child who has difficulty identifying an I can't you can say, "If you feel powerful today and have no I can'ts to speak of, think of a time when you did and just keep writing."  As you write keep trusting whatever comes to mind; it doesn't have to make sense. It's okay if you repeat one I can't over and over again. Now, I'm going to turn on some music and we are going to take ten minutes to write all the I can'ts that come up...Cue music on.

Sharing & Tearing:
Now we are going get into a circle. Ask each child to share their I Can'ts with the group, destroy them by tearing them, and put them in the center of the circle.  Remember to tell them, "this is voluntary, and you don't have to share anything you don't want to."  Even if you don't want to share, I will ask each of you to tear your I Can't and add it to the pile. 
Continue until each child has had a turn.  Then have all the children walk into the middle of the circle and stomp on the I can't pile.

Tell the children, "now that you have destroyed your I can'ts I want you to remember that you are strong and capable and you can do anything!"  Before we go back to our seat I want each child to say out loud something that they "can" do but thought they couldn't do. Give examples, such as, "If you thought that you couldn't get good grades, I want you to say 'I can get good grades!' After you say your I can, you may sit down."

After each person has shared, have the participants sit back down and begin the I Can portion of this workshop. 

 
 I Can statement created by a child
 

I Can Statements/Drawings:
We are ready to focus on our I Can's. I don't want to hear any more "I can'ts", those were left in the pile.  Remember, you are strong and capable! 
Tell the children that we are going to gather all of their I Can statements/drawings and use them in the exhibit but they will get to create something for themselves too! Ask them to think about all of the things that they  can do, and choose one that is really important to them. Ask them to pick a color paper to represent this "I Can"... is your I Can purple, green, pink?  Then write or draw a picture of your "I Can" (turn happy music on).   Give ten minutes for the I Can statement writing/draing. Cue music off.

 
  I Can statement created by an adult
 

I Can Shrinky Dink:
Now we are going to create an I Can shrinky dink to remind us that WE CAN! Don't worry if your I Can seems impossible. Be brave! (Cue music back on.)

Step 1:
Keeping in mind all of the things you can do, use colored pencils to write words, colors, shapes, or scribbles on the Shrinky Dink to help you remember that YOU CAN! 

You can use a template or draw on the Shrinky Dink. Add color to fill in your design.

Step 2:
When you are finished coloring, if you like, cut out your I Can shrinky with scissors.  Make sure to punch a hole in the shrinky dink so it can be hung.  Make sure your don't punch your hole too close to the edge of the shrinky paper, as it may break after cooking.

Step 3:
Now the I Can shrinkys are ready for baking. Place the shrinky dink, colored side up, on either a small piece of a brown paper bag, or a metal tray, or a piece of aluminum foil; then place the paper, tray, or foil in the toaster oven.

Step 4:
Cook the shrinkys at 300 degrees for 1-3 minutes.  Watch as your shrinky dink shrinks!  After the shrinky lies flat, allow an additional 15 seconds of baking time to complete the process.  If you pull the shrinkys out prematurely, it is okay to put them back in the oven.

While the shrinkys are cooking have the participants complete the 2012 Art/Photography Release.  Make sure they leave their contact info so they can be invited to the exhibit.

Step 5:
Remove paper, tray, or foil and let Shrinky Dinks cool.  If you like, you can add ribbon so you can hang your I Can shrinky.  You can also add beads if you choose.

Closing:
Have each child share how it felt to destroy their "I Can'ts" and/or create their "I Cans."

Thank the participants and remind then to look at their I Can shrinky dink as a reminder that they can do anything!

Row.str_name: Lotus flower using colored paper and paper fastener
Row.txt_code:
Adult Windows leader Ginny Walsh printed the lotus template onto colored paper (eliminating the use of watercolors) and used paper fasteners instead of glue to hold the layers of the flower together. This variation is perfect if you're trying to shorten the amount of time the workshop takes to complete and makes for an easy clean up.
   
   
 Lotus Flowers created by Ginny Walsh's clients

Row.str_name: Lotus flower using colored paper and paper fastener
Row.txt_code:
Adult Windows leader Ginny Walsh printed the lotus template onto colored paper (eliminating the use of watercolors) and used paper fasteners instead of glue to hold the layers of the flower together.  This variation is perfect if you're trying to shorten the amount of time the workshop takes to complete and makes for an easy clean up.
   
   
 Lotus Flowers created by Ginny Walsh's clients
To make smaller Totem Poles, you can use toilet paper or paper towel rolls as the base.  We have included templates for the smaller body and wings that were also created by Rudy Hernandez.

Row.str_name: The Monster I See By Ricky Spenner
Row.txt_code:
The Monster in Me is one of my favorite workshops because it allows for so much wiggle room and many variations. I don't think I've ever had the same workshop twice while running it.  The workshop itself took on its own form as we went along. I started with the intention of doing the Monster in Me workshop, but the monsters the children created started to become the "monsters" in their own lives--bullies, abusers, stories they saw on the news, etc. By the time we finished, every child's monster was not one inside of them, but one they have seen/experienced, hence the change in title.

This workshop was perfect for an exhibit because it is so very powerful.  We called the exhibit "The Monster I See: A Child's View of Violence." Putting a child's perspective on the violence in their lives had a great impact on many of the exhibit goers, and I received feedback later in the week from the venue telling me the same thing. We had a few finished Monster in Me drawings from children who had left shelter a long while ago as well, which were just as powerful. In fact, one of the Monster in Me drawings garnered a lot of attention. The stark contrast between inside/outside emotions and behaviors sparked quite a few discussions.
     
  Advocates of Ozaukee Exhibit Flyer
  The Monster I See
