Row.str_name: "I Love You, I Forgive You, I Let You Go"
Row.txt_code:
As an alternative to the Relaxation exercise, ask the participants to complete a letting go journaling exercise. Using a journal, or journaling paper, and a pen, ask the women to think about the expression, "I love you, I forgive you, I let you go." Give the women a few minutes to think ab
out who and what they would like to let go of, even if it is a feeling that they have about themselves. Remind them that we all hang on to certain people, places, and things. It is a part of human nature! However, the people and things that are hardest to let go of are those who and that we care about the most. We must first acknowledge that a piece of us still loves (or once loved) those people and things. Even if we are unable to feel it at the time, simply by thinking, saying or writing, "I forgive you" releases the tension and anxiety that the anger holds. Finally, paired with breath exhalation, we can let that feeling, person, or thing go. After explaining the process, instruct the women to write, think, or repeat this mantra to themselves. Each time they do so, focus on that person, place or thing through creating a picture in their mind or on the paper while writing, thinking, or quietly saying out loud, "I love you, I forgive you, I let you go." Have the women repeat this phrase over and over for five minutes, then they can begin creating!

An optional closing for this workshop was submitted to us by Susan Burke from Heritage House North in Anaheim, CA. At the end of the art sharing, hand each participant a golf tee (purchased at any local golfing store or golf course) and tell them that if they "take the "t" out of c an't, they can." This will serve as an encouraging reminder for them that, sometimes, changing "can't" to "can" can be very simple and possible!

An optional closing for this workshop was submitted to us by Susan Burke from Heritage House North in Anaheim, CA. At the end of the art sharing, hand each participant a golf tee (purchased at any local golfing store or golf course) and tell them that if they "take the "t" out of can't, they can." This will serve as an encouraging reminder for them that, sometimes, changing "can't" to "can" can be very simple and possible!

Journaling/Warm up:
"First, pick a color that feels safe to you or speaks to you or simply use your journal. We are going to journal about 3 different types of needs we all have: the needs of our body, our mind and those of our spirit. As you can see that I have done with this paper, please take a piece of paper (choose a color that makes you feel comfortable and safe or even strong and hopeful). Fold that paper into thirds lengthwise, like you would a letter. On the top of the first column, write the word Physical, on the second Emotional, and on the third Spiritual. If you are using your journal, you can instead draw two lines on the page to designate three separate sections.

I'm going to talk a little bit about each of these three needs and give you two minutes after each one to write and reflect on this need for yourself. Keep in mind that there is no right or wrong way to do this journaling exercise. You can write sentences, words, lists, draw symbols, shapes, or anything else you like. The most important thing is that you don't censor yourself! Just allow your thoughts to flow onto your paper without judgment. What you write does not have to make sense to anyone but you! While you are journaling, your only job is to not stop writing! You will write about your physical, emotional, and spiritual needs doe a total of ten minutes. (You might want to play soft background music during this journaling portion).

"Physical needs are what we usually think about first. What are your physical needs in order to be safe, happy and healthy? (For example: We need to be free from harm. We need shelter and a safe place to live. We need good nutrition: healthy food and clean water. We need exercise - keeping our bodies healthy and strong. We need rest, giving us energy to do what we need to do, like succeeding at work or going to school.) In the first column, begin writing words, sentences, symbols or shapes to represent your physical needs (allow two minutes for this).

"Another need that may be a little harder to think about, but just as important are our emotional needs. What are your emotional needs in order to feel safe, happy, and healthy? (Examples are: feeling understood, feeling accepted and heard.) Knowing that we are loved and appreciated also gives us the feeling of having emotional support. Relaxation, fun, and friendship help us to find emotional balance. Having boundaries, realistic expectations, and a positive attitude are other ways of supporting our emotional health. Now in the second column, begin journaling about your emotional needs (allow two minutes for this).

"Finally, we will address our spiritual needs. What does your spirit need to give you peace? Is it the ability to forgive, have patience or acceptance of others? Do you need quiet time to reflect, meditate, or pray? Do you need to do good deeds or help others feel uplifted? Do you need "me" time to care for your soul? In the third column write words, sentences, shapes, or symbols to reflect your spiritual needs (allow two minutes for this).

"Thank you for taking the time to reflect on (and honor) your own personal needs. Remember that you are worth it and representing your needs shows that they are, too!"

You can start this workshop by having participants create their own feeling targets by writing feeling words on the paper plates (or other paper targets). You can let them come up with their own feeling words and even encourage them to write the words in a way that expresses that emotion. For example, one person might write "relaxed" in flowing letters with colors that seem calm to them while another writes "frustrated" in jagged letters with colors that seem more active to them.

You can start this workshop by having participants create their own feeling targets by writing feeling words on the paper plates (or other paper targets). You can let them come up with their own feeling words and even encourage them to write the words in a way that expresses that emotion. For example, one person might write "relaxed" in flowing letters with colors that seem calm to them while another writes "frustrated" in jagged letters with colors that seem more active to them.

Row.str_name: Sun Kisses, Moon Hugs Card Making
Row.txt_code: Create a Sun Kisses, Moon Hugs card to someone/something you miss. The children may or may not send these. The ideas is to express the feelings, thoughts, memories or wishes they hold inside and connect them in a way that supports them.

Row.str_name: Sun Kisses, Moon Hugs Charm Bracelet
Row.txt_code: Using Shrinky Dinks (butterfly templates, leaves, flowers, trees, etc.)  create a charm bracelet with a charm for each of the things or people they want to stay connected to or to represent people or things you miss.

Row.str_name: Sun Kisses, Moon Hugs Scavenger Hunt in Nature
Row.txt_code:
Lead the children on a walk outdoors (or assign as homework with parents). Have them look for signs of love in nature such as heart-shaped leaves or stones, butterflies, clouds, branches making a X shape or things with a O shape to represent hugs and kisses.
The children can then journal or write a poem about what they found.

Row.str_name: Sun Kisses, Moon Hugs Parenting Workshop Variation
Row.txt_code: This workshop can be used as a parenting workshop to give moms and dads permission to open up communication around issues of loss, separation, and death and to provide their children with comforting ways to feel connected with those emotions brought up. Encourage parents to read this story to their children and gently ask them questions regarding how they feel about death, loss, separation, etc. Remind and reassure the children that there are always ways to stay connected to those we love and this book can help us to see and feel these connections. After reading and discussing the story and its meaning, invite a parent and child creation portion in which the family members can create their drawings together.

Row.str_name: Sun Kisses, Moon Hugs Card Making Workshop Variation
Row.txt_code: Create a <u>Sun Kisses, Moon Hugs</u> card to someone or something you miss. This card can express the feelings, thoughts, memories or wishes they hold inside and connect them to a person or thing they miss. The participants can even turn their drawings into a card and can create in any way that supports them. They may or may not choose to send the cards to the person or thing they miss.

Row.str_name: Sun Kisses, Moon Hugs Collage Making Workshop Variation
Row.txt_code: Invite the participants to reflect on the story's meaning and message and journal about what they may be missing literally or figuratively. Encourage them to create a collage to keep as a reminder of happy memories they have or a vision collage of what they want to create in their future.

Row.str_name: Sun Kisses, Moon Hugs Charm Bracelet Workshop Variation
Row.txt_code: Using clay or shrinky dinks (butterfly templates, leaves, flowers, trees, etc.) invite the participants to create a charm bracelet with a charm representing each of the things or people they want to stay connected to.

< !--[if gte mso 9]> Objective:
To give the family an opportunity to create gifts that they can make for each other.  To help them notice how giving gifts from the heart can be very special and wonderful gifts.

Materials:
Construction paper
Markers
Scissors (if you have "edger scissors," it's nice to give a special edge to the coupons)
Glue sticks
Glitter, stickers, etc.

Introduction:
Today I want you to think about something that you could create that would make someone in your family happy.  Mothers Day, a Birthday, or any day is an opportunity to give someone you love a special Gift Coupon.  It is one way the family can show how they care about each other.

Opening Circle:
Encourage a sharing of feelings and then have all the families stand/sit in a circle for an appreciation circle.  Ask the family members to hold hands and say something that they appreciate about the family member to their left or right. Continue going around in the circle in this order, so that everyone can share and be appreciated.

Creation:
Every one will have the opportunity to create Gift Coupons for someone in their family.  It could be a hug, an extra chore for the week, a backrub or anything you think the person would enjoy.  The important thing to remember is how good it feels to give of yourself and to receive a heartfelt gift.

Closing Circle:
Share your coupons and something you learned from doing this workshop.  How did it make you to feel to give these Gift Coupons?  How did it feel to receive them?

Additional Information:
You may want to try this workshop during various holidays. Holidays in particular can be a challenging time of the year. Moms and children may be missing their home, old traditions or things from their past.  Ask each person to share the good and bad feelings they've noticed inside them and around them during the holiday.  Whoever doesn't want to share any thoughts can pass.

Note:
In leading this workshop, it is very rewarding to witness the family actually realize that the most important gifts are those they don't need to buy.  It is challenging, but important to help them face the reality that they may not have enough money for many of the things they want (and maybe even some of what they need at times).

Creating without a template
 
  Creating with a template
 
   Don't forget to punch a hole!
 
 Adding ribbon and beads
Materials:
Shrinky Dink material (Ruff-N-Ready)
Adult hand template
Child hand template
Permanent markers
Colored pencils and sharpeners
Scissors
Hole puncher
Toaster oven
Beads (optional)
1/8 inch ribbon, yarn, embroidery thread, or craft wire

Creation:
"Now that you have identified an I CAN, it is time to create a Shrinky Dink to serve as a tangible reminder of your I CAN. Place your I CAN message on the shrinky paper however you like. Your I CAN expression can be words, swirls, colors, shapes. Anything goes! You are all incredibly powerful individuals and I invite you to be bold, let go of judgment, and allow your creative juices to flow!" 

Step One:
When creating the Shrinky Dinks, invite the participants to use the templates provided or create their own designs. Remind them to color on the rough side of the Shrinky Dink if using colored pencils; they can use permanent markers on both sides.

Step Two:
When the participants are finished coloring, they may use scissors to cut their Shrinky Dink into a shape. Then they will use the hole punch to create a hole in the Shrinky Dink. Remind them to be sure not to punch the hole too close to the edge of the Shrinky Dink paper.

Step Three:
Once the group members are done coloring, cutting, and punching a hole into their Shrinky Dink, they are ready for baking. Place the Shrinky Dink on a flat metal tray and place inside the toaster oven. We have found it is best to place a piece of a paper bag on the metal tray inside the oven with a corner turned up to make it easier to handle. Bake at 300 degrees until Shrinky Dink has completely flattened (this will take about one minute). Watch the amazing transformation! Remove the Shrinky Dink and allow it to cool.

Step Four:
Now the Shrinky Dink is ready for decorating with ribbon and beads. Thread ribbon through the hole and add beads. If you do not have access to ribbon you can just have the participants string the Shrinky Dinks from embroidery thread, yarn or wire. 
 
 
 
 I CAN shrinky created without a template I CAN shrinky created with a template

Row.str_name: I CAN WE CAN Paper Quilt
Row.txt_code:
Paper quit made by children at Good Shepherd
 
Materials:
White card stock
Lined paper
Pre-printed specialty paper (must be at least 8 1/2 x 11 in size)
Pencils
Markers
Crayons
Scissors
Glue sticks

Pre-workshop Prep:
To expedite the creation process and ensure your quit is proportional, you will want to pre- cut paper for the participants to create their art on and separate, lined paper for them to write words to accompany their art piece. One easy way to do this is to use full sheets (8 1/2" by 11") of pre-printed specialty paper as a background.

Materials 
Materials:
Super Sculpey Polymer Clay (have multiple colors available)
Toaster Oven
Hand shaped cookie cutter
Small coffee straws or skewers
1/8" ribbon, yarn, embroidery thread or craft wire
Beads (optional)
Permanent markers (metallic colors look great on dark colored clay)
White-out pens

Pre-workshop prep:
Prepare several Sculpey balls, enough for each person, in various colors. It is a great idea to demonstrate how to make swirly or marbled shapes out of Sculpey.

 
 
  Sculpey "snake" using 3 colors 
   
  Twisting Sculpey colors 
   
  Flatten Sculpey 
   
  Roll Sculpey to about 1/4 of an inch 
   
  Cut Sculpey with a cookie cutter 
   
  Make a hole to hang the hand 
Creation:
Step One:
To blend the clay, choose at least three colors. Use no more than a pinch of each color. When choosing your clay, you may want to choose colors that feel powerful to you - any colors that come to mind when you think, "I CAN."

Step Two:
Roll each color into a "snake."

Step Three:
Wrap each "snake" around each other like a candy-cane and twist together.
Tip: Use at least three different colors of clay when blending them together. It also looks great when the colors complement each other.

Step Four:
Keep twisting the "snakes" until the colors are blended just the way you want them.
Tip: Be careful not to over-blend the colors as they can start to look muddy.

Step Five:
Roll the "snakes" into a ball. If you want, repeat steps 4 and 5 several times to create a more marbled effect.

Step Six:
Using a pen or a marker roll the ball flat to be about 1/4 inch thick. Use a hand-shaped cookie cutter to cut the clay into the shape of a hand. Use a coffee straw, skewer or pencil to make a hole at the top so you can hang the hand after it bakes.
Tips:
1) Before using the cookie cutter, pIck up and flip the clay periodically so it doesn't stick to the paper/surface you are working on.  
2) It's important to make sure that the clay is at least 1/4 of an inch thick; if they clay is any thinner the hand will easily break.
3) If the clay is sticking to the cookie cutter. it is helpful to put the clay (after the balls have been flattened) in the refrigerator and then use the cookie cutter after the clay is cold.
4) When making the hole in the hand, make sure it is not too close to the edge (to prevent the hand from breaking).

Step Seven:
Using a foil lined tray, place the clay hand in the oven. Bake the Sculpey at 275 degrees for 15 minutes (for each ¼ inch of clay thickness). Always allow the clay to cool completely before handling it.

Step Eight:
"Now that you have identified an I CAN, it is time to create on your I CAN clay hand to serve as a tangible reminder of your I CAN. Place your I CAN message on the clay hand using the permanent markers and/or white out pens however you like. Your I CAN expression can be words, swirls, colors, shapes. Anything goes! You are all incredibly powerful individuals and I invite you to be bold, let go of judgment, and allow your creative juices to flow!"
Tip: If the clay hands are dark in color, metallic permanent markers work great to make sure the color stands out.

Step Nine:
Encourage the participants to use ribbon, yarn, embroidery thread or wire to hang their I CAN hand and use beads to decorate.
Tip: If you offer beads, keep in mind that it will add significant time to the creation process.
   
  I CAN Spread Awareness finished clay creation

Hand made with metallic paper
  
  
 3D I CAN hand
  
Materials:
Paper in assorted styles, textures, patterns and colors (rice, metallic, novelty, card stock, etc.)
Glue sticks
Permanent markers (metallic colors look great on dark paper)
White out pens
Scissors

Technical Demonstration:
Share about the different types of paper and writing utensils that are available. Demonstrate how the permanent markers and white out pens draw beautifully on every type of paper. You may want to show your participants the different effects you can get by layering the paper. You can also show them how adding a background image can add hidden meaning and also make a collage "pop!"

Another option is to encourage participants to select materials and glue them down without asking yourself 'why' you are choosing these particular materials. Work 'from your instincts' and cut, glue, scribble, and draw out anything that feels right at the moment.

Another wonderful collage technique is to not use scissors. Tearing the paper adds more texture!

Creation:
﻿"Now that you have identified an I CAN, it is time to collage a paper hand to serve as a tangible reminder of your I CAN. Using the collage materials and glue, create your I CAN however you like. Your I CAN expression can be words, swirls, colors, shapes. Anything goes! You are all incredibly powerful individuals and I invite you to be bold, let go of judgment, and allow your creative juices to flow!"
  
 
 Tissue paper collage I CAN hand   Rice paper collage

Wet henna design with bindis
Henna Background and History:
Henna tattoos are a kind of temporary body art involving the application of a natural dye paste which leaves behind a reddish-brown color. It is traditionally applied to women's hands and feet for religious ceremony, weddings and other celebrations.



Materials:
Ready-made henna paste - before you purchase, check the expiration date and ensure there are no additives or preservatives and no para-phenylenediamine (PPD)
Plastic bowl and spoon
Lemon juice
Sugar
Plastic wrap
Triangular piece of cellophane or mylar, or squeeze bottle
Toothpick or straight pen
Cotton balls
Butter knife or other blunt object
Toilet paper
Plastic wrap
Tape

Pre-workshop prep:
We strongly recommend watching a video about how to make and apply henna. YouTube has many examples, this is our favorite. You will also want to apply a very small drop of the henna on each of your participants skin to test if they are allergic. The participant will feel a cooling sensation upon application. Please note this is a very important step as henna can permanently scar skin if the person has an allergy to it. Also make sure to avoid "black henna" ink containing para-phenylenediamine (PPD), a coal-tar product that is approved for use in hair dye but is known to cause skin reactions in some people. Avoid using any henna pastes that contain preservatives or additives. Traditional reddish-brown henna is not part of the warning. Please note that henna will stain any fabric it touches so make sure to use tablecloths and aprons.

Creation: (either follow the steps below or watch this video)
Step 1:
Check the date on the ready-made henna paste, the fresher the paste, the darker the henna will appear. Once purchased, it should be kept in your refrigerator for further freshness.

Step 2:
Put Henna paste in a plastic bowl, cover tightly with plastic wrap, and let it sit in a warm place for 30 minutes to several hours. You will know it is ready when it turns from green to dark brown or puddles of liquid have formed on top.

Step 3:
If you do not have a squeeze bottle, roll a piece of cellophane or mylar into a cone shape.  Tape the seem, fill the cone about half way with henna paste, fold the top down and tape it shut. Cut off tip of cone right before you begin applying. If you have a squeeze bottle, fill the bottle with henna paste.

Step 4:
Using a cone or squeeze bottle, apply henna paste to clean, dry skin.

Step 5:
"Now that you have identified an I CAN, it is time to create an I CAN on your hand to serve as a tangible reminder of the I CAN you choose to embrace today. Using the henna paste create your I CAN however you like. Your I CAN expression can be words, swirls, colors, shapes. Anything goes! You are all incredibly powerful individuals and I invite you to be bold, let go of judgment, and allow your creative juices to flow!" Use a toothpick or pin to fix any mistakes and clear the applicator.

Step 6:
When henna paste is dry, use a cotton ball to dab a glaze of equal parts lemon juice and sugar. This can help to preserve the tattoo, allowing it to remain on the skin for as long as 3 weeks. According to HennaTattoos.com, it is important to avoid exposing the tattoo to direct sunlight while the paste is still on. To ensure that your tattoo lasts as long as possible, avoid wetting it for at least one hour after it has been applied. When you are in the shower or in the bathtub, try to gently clean the area with water and mild soap instead of using an exfoliating wash or loofah sponge which could wear away at the dye, causing your tattoo to fade. If possible, let the henna dry for up to twelve hours. If you leave it on over night, cover the henna with first toilet paper and then plastic wrap.

Step 7:
After the henna has set and dried, flake it off using a plastic spoon or blunt object. You can even rub your hands together to allow for the pieces to flake off. Avoid washing with soap for 24 hours to allow the henna stain to last longer. You can squeeze a lemon on top to allow for further vibrancy and wash it off after 20 minutes.
  
  Hand after henna has dried and been removed

Materials:
  
  Pre-cut I CAN hands displayed at I CAN WE CAN workshop
Paper in assorted colors (card stock is preferred)
Adult hand template
Child hand template
Small hand template with fingers together (works great to create a bookmark)
Pencil
Scissors
Permanent markers (metallic colors look great)
White-out pens

 
 
 
  Artist holding her pre-cut I CAN hand 
Pre-workshop prep:
Use a template or trace your hand (with a pencil) on a piece of heavyweight paper (card stock is ideal). Then use scissors to cut out the hand. Please note that if you are cutting multiple hands, this can be time consuming and may leave your hands feeling sore. If possible, recruit volunteers to help trace and cut the hands.

Creation:
"Now that you have identified an I CAN, it is time to create your very own paper I CAN hand.  Your creation will serve as a tangible reminder of the I CAN you have chosen to embrace today. Place your I CAN on the paper however you like. Your I CAN expression can be words, swirls, colors, shapes. Anything goes! You are all incredibly powerful individuals and I invite you to be bold, let go of judgment, and allow your creative juices to flow!"

& nbsp; Creating without a template
 
  Creating with a template
 
   Don't forget to punch a hole!
 
 Adding ribbon and beads
Materials:
Shrinky Dink material (Ruff-N-Ready)
Adult hand template
Child hand template
Permanent markers
Colored pencils and sharpeners
Scissors
Hole puncher
Toaster oven
Beads (optional)
1/8 inch ribbon, yarn, embroidery thread, or craft wire

Creation:
"Now that you have identified an I CAN, it is time to create a Shrinky Dink to serve as a tangible reminder of your I CAN. Place your I CAN message on the shrinky paper however you like. Your I CAN expression can be words, swirls, colors, shapes. Anything goes! You are all incredibly powerful individuals and I invite you to be bold, let go of judgment, and allow your creative juices to flow!" 

Step One:
When creating the Shrinky Dinks, invite the participants to use the templates provided or create their own designs. Remind them to color on the rough side of the Shrinky Dink if using colored pencils; they can use permanent markers on both sides.

Step Two:
When the participants are finished coloring, they may use scissors to cut their Shrinky Dink into a shape. Then they will use the hole punch to create a hole in the Shrinky Dink. Remind them to be sure not to punch the hole too close to the edge of the Shrinky Dink paper.

Step Three:
Once the group members are done coloring, cutting, and punching a hole into their Shrinky Dink, they are ready for baking. Place the Shrinky Dink on a flat metal tray and place inside the toaster oven. We have found it is best to place a piece of a paper bag on the metal tray inside the oven with a corner turned up to make it easier to handle. Bake at 300 degrees until Shrinky Dink has completely flattened (this will take about one minute). Watch the amazing transformation! Remove the Shrinky Dink and allow it to cool.

Step Four:
Now the Shrinky Dink is ready for decorating with ribbon and beads. Thread ribbon through the hole and add beads. If you do not have access to ribbon you can just have the participants string the Shrinky Dinks from embroidery thread, yarn or wire. 
 
 
 
 I CAN shrinky created without a template I CAN shrinky created with a template

Materials

Toaster Oven
Hand shaped cookie cutter

Row.str_name: Find Your I CAN: Connecting to the Community
Row.txt_code:
Find Your I CAN: Connecting to the Community

Step 1: Upload Your Artwork

  1. Take a photo the I CAN shrink art.
  2. Go to icanwecan.awbw.org/upload.
  3. In the text box where it says "Title," type in the words exactly as they are written on your I CAN shrink art. (This will help people to find your I CAN artwork.)
  4. In the text box where it says "Artist name (as you want it displayed)," you can type your name, a psuedonym, or leave it blank.
  5. In the text that says "Organization/Company name," you can type in your agency, company, or organization name, or leave it blank.
  6. Upload your photo by clicking on the "Browse..." button to locate the image on your computer.
  7. In the text box that says "Words to accompany this piece," write any additional words or explanation you'd like to go with your artwork.
  8. Click the "SAVE" button.

 

 

Step 2: Attach the I CAN WE CAN Tag

  1. Attach the tag to your artwork with a ribbon or string so people will know what to do with your art when they find it. If you want to print your own tags, here is a double-sided version and a single-sided version. You'll need to cut out the tags and punch a hole in each one. Tip: Printing on cardstock makes the tags more durable.
  2. If you'd like, you can also add beads or multiple colors of ribbon. Tip: If you're using ribbon, cut it on an angle so that it's easier to pass through the holes.

Step 3: Put Your I CAN Out in the World

  1. Choose a location to leave your I CAN for others to find. It could be hanging on a fence post, in a bowl of other I CAN art pieces to be given out as party favors, pinned up on a bulletin board, or in any place that feels exciting to you!
  2. On or before the Day of Action on October 16, put your I CAN out in the world in your chosen location so people can find it and respond to it.

Step 4: Check for Support

  1. Check the photo of your I CAN shrink art to see if anyone has found it and left you a comment of support or solidarity by visiting this link: icanwecan.awbw.org/find.
  2. Type your title (or artist name, if you used one) in the box that says "Search words."
  3. Click on the blue "SEARCH" button.
  4. You will see a list of I CAN artworks that match your search. Click on your artwork.
  5. Read the comments at the bottom of the page and respond if you wish!


Closing Circle:
Now that you've created your I CAN art to send out into the world, how are you feeling? How do you think people will respond to your work? What do you want people to think when they find your I CAN? How can you share this experience with the people in your life?

Materials:
  
  Pre-cut I CAN hands displayed at I CAN WE CAN workshop
Paper in assorted colors (card stock is preferred)
Adult hand template
Child hand template
Small hand template with fingers together (works great to create a bookmark)
Pencil
Scissors
Permanent markers (metallic colors look great on dark colored clay)
White-out pens

 
 
 
  Artist holding her pre-cut I CAN hand 
Pre-workshop prep:
Use a template or trace your hand (with a pencil) on a piece of heavy weight paper (card stock is ideal). Then use scissors to cut the hand. Please note that if you are cutting multiple hands, this can be time consuming and may leave your hands feeling sore. If possible recruit volunteers to help trace and cut the hands.

Creation:
"Now that you have identified an I CAN, it is time to create your very own paper I CAN hand.  Your creation will serve as a tangible reminder of the I CAN you chose to embrace today. Place your I CAN on the paper however you like. Your I CAN expression can be words, swirls, colors, shapes. Anything goes! You are all incredibly powerful individuals and I invite you to be bold, let go of judgment, and allow your creative juices to flow!"

Row.str_name: Find Your I CAN - Variation of I CAN WE CAN Community Engagement Project
Row.txt_code:
Be a part of the I CAN WE CAN action by creating your own I CAN art to raise awareness, support others, and get support for yourself! You can create your own art or lead a group in this project. The directions below give you detailed instructions for participating in Find Your I CAN using shrinkable plastic ("shrinky-dinks"), but you can do this project with any supplies at all (e.g. paper, scratch art, clay, etc.). You can even participate in Find Your I CAN virtually by going to the online gallery at icanwecan.awbw.org and using the social media buttons to comment and share artwork and stories!

Step 1: Create Your I CAN Statement

  1. Take a moment to reflect on what you can do to help end violence in your own life or in your community. Don't worry if the I CAN that comes to you seems too small to be important or too big to be possible.
  2. On the shrinkable plastic, draw your I CAN (e.g. "I CAN Listen," "I CAN Speak Up," "I CAN_______"), making sure that your I CAN statement is large and clearly readable (this will help make sure that people can find your uploaded photo). You can either use colored pencils on the rough side or permanent markers on either side of the shrinkable plastic. Feel free to embellish your I CAN statement by tracing one of the provided hand templates or adding other drawings or doodles.
  3. Punch a hole at the top of your artwork so you can attach the tag during Step 4. Leave at least a 1/4" between the edge of the plastic and your hole.

Optional Variation: If you would like to keep your I CAN creation for yourself as well as put one into the community, create a duplicate I CAN statement by tracing your artwork before shrinking it. To make the tracing easier, temporarily tape the two shrinkable plastic sheets together.





Step 2: Shrink Your Artwork

  1. Preheat an oven (toaster or conventional is fine) to 300˚F.
  2. Bake your shrink art in the oven for a couple of minutes. Your artwork will curl up then flatten. After it flattens, take it out to cool.

Tip: Place your shrink art on a paper bag cut-out for easy removal.


Step 3: Upload Your Artwork

  1. Take a photo of your I CAN shrink art.
  2. Go to icanwecan.awbw.org/upload.
  3. In the text box where it says "Title," type in the words exactly as they are written on your I CAN shrink art. (This will help people to find your I CAN artwork.)
  4. In the text box where it says "Artist name (as you want it displayed)," you can type your name, a psuedonym, or leave it blank.
  5. In the text that says "Organization/Company name," you can type in your agency, company, or organization name, or leave it blank.
  6. Upload your photo by clicking on the "Browse..." button to locate the image on your computer.
  7. In the text box that says "Words to accompany this piece," write any additional words or explanation you'd like to go with your artwork.
  8. Click the "SAVE" button.

 

 

Step 4: Attach the I CAN WE CAN Tag

  1. Attach the tag to your artwork with a ribbon or string so people will know what to do with your art when they find it. If you want to print your own tags, here is a double-sided version and a single-sided version. You'll need to cut out the tags and punch a hole in each one. Tip: Printing on cardstock makes the tags more durable.
  2. If you'd like, you can also add beads or multiple colors of ribbon. Tip: If you're using ribbon, cut it on an angle so that it's easier to pass through the holes.

Step 5: Put Your I CAN Out in the World

  1. Choose a location to leave your I CAN for others to find. It could be hanging on a fence post, in a bowl of other I CAN art pieces to be given out as party favors, pinned up on a bulletin board, or in any place that feels exciting to you!
  2. On or before the Day of Action, put your I CAN out in the world in your chosen location so people can find it and respond to it.

Step 6: Check for Support

  1. Check the photo of your I CAN shrink art to see if anyone has found it and left you a comment of support or solidarity by visiting this link: icanwecan.awbw.org/find.
  2. Type your title (or artist name, if you used one) in the box that says "Search words."
  3. Click on the blue "SEARCH" button.
  4. You will see a list of I CAN artworks that match your search. Click on your artwork.
  5. Read the comments at the bottom of the page and respond if you wish!

While we strongly encourage walking the river as embodied healing can have a deeper impact than just words, if your group is shy, here are additional options for sharing:
  1. Table Share: participants can share at the table, one at a time, choosing to sit or stand at their seat when presenting.
  2. Mini Art Gallery: participants who wish to share can leave their artwork and River Story worksheet at their place at the table and everyone can walk around and view the "art gallery."
  3. Paired Sharing: participants partner up and share their River Stories with one another.

While we strongly encourage walking the river as embodied healing can have a deeper impact than just words, if your group is shy, here are additional options for sharing:

Row.str_name: Expressive Crayon for Teens and Older Youth
Row.txt_code:
Description
In this simple yet powerful warm-up, participants can safely express any emotions they have been holding inside by scribbling freely.

Materials:
Crayons              
Paper



  Time frame:
Introduction                         3 min
Preparation (optional)          5 min
Creation                               2 min
Closing                               10 min
  
                     Total Time: 15-20 min
  

Set Up
Place crayons and paper on the table so that they are easily accessible to participants.

Introduction 
Welcome participants and remind them that this is their window of time to practice honoring their feelings, needs, and thoughts. Let them know that they get to choose what their participation looks like. For example, participation might mean sitting quietly with their head down, just playing with the supplies, trying out all the suggestions you give, or anything else that feels right to them.

Start by asking each participant to share one or two words of how they are feeling right now. (Remind them that "I don't know" or "pass" are perfectly acceptable answers.)

Preparation (optional)
 
 
 Circular Doodles
 
   
 Angular Scribbles on Top
of Circular Doodles
 
"We're going to begin by warming up our bodies and getting comfortable with the supplies. So I invite you to take a piece of paper and any crayon you like and just begin doodling by making random circular motions. Don't worry if you break the crayon or about what your doodle looks like--see if you can just let yourself feel the movement of your arm without judging it." Give the participants 30-60 seconds to draw circular scribbles.

NOTE: It can be helpful if you participate with your group, so that they can see you being playful and relaxed with your scribbles and doodles.

"Now add to your scribble by picking a new crayon and with your other hand, make fast and angular motions." Give the participants 30-60 seconds to draw angular scribbles.

"Finally, using both hands together, make either angular or circular motions using the two colors together." Give the participants 30-60 seconds to create, and invite them to find a pausing place.

Offer participants a moment to share anything they'd like to about their experience, and then ask them to take a new piece of paper or flip their current piece of paper over.

Creation
   
 Expressive Crayon depicting anger. 
   
 Expressive Crayon depicting happiness. 
"Choose any emotion you like. I invite you to pick one that you feel like you haven't had permission to feel. For some of you that may be anger, for others it may be grief, aggression, confidence, love, or something else.

"So go ahead and choose an emotion and crayon to represent that emotion. Consider going with your first thought--you can always change the emotion or the color later if you like.

"In a moment, I'm going to invite you to express that emotion on the paper in front of you for two minutes. When we start, I want to use your crayon to express that emotion on the paper. Think about how you might move your arm to express that emotion. This can look like scribbling or tapping, moving slowly or quickly, or anything else that you feel like doing." It can be helpful to give examples in the air with a crayon and your own body movements as you say this.

"Don't worry about what it looks like, or even ripping the paper or breaking the crayons--just take this activity where you need it to go. Is everyone ready?"

Give participants two minutes to explore their chosen emotion. When two minutes are up, you can say, "Find a pausing place so we can take a moment to reflect on what that was like."

Closing
Give the participants an opportunity to share anything they like about their scribbles, their chosen feeling, or whatever they noticed by participating. It can also be helpful to remind participants that they are welcome to pass if they don't feel like sharing and that each person's representation of an emotion could be different, and that is okay.

End by validating each person's experience and their taking a window of time to honor themselves.
Click here to see the Expressive Crayon Warm Up variation that includes additional emotions.

Warm-up: Gifting Myself
Ask the group to stand in a circle with enough space in between each person to move freely. If you have limited space, this warm-up can be done at a table, sitting or standing.

"Now that we've learned a little about some of the personal needs that we might have. I want you to think about a personal need that you want to gift yourself. I'm going to give you a few directions that will invite you to think quietly to yourself about your personal needs. I will then invite you to use your body, words, or both to show what you were thinking about. You can follow my directions completely or you can choose another way to participate that honors your thoughts and feelings. Any way you choose to participate is OK, even if it's just observing.

For example, I might want to gift myself relaxation because I've had such a long day. Or, I might want to give myself love because I've been feeling a little down lately. While you're thinking about this gift for yourself, if you feel comfortable enough to do so, think of a body movement that you would like to share that goes along with your gift. For example, if I give myself the gift of relaxation, I might yawn loudly, stretch and take a deep breath. If I gift myself love, I might give myself a big hug.

"I'll give you a minute to think about the personal need and the movement that goes along with it. As you're thinking, you might want to think about a need that you've ignored in the past and you'd really like to focus on.

"We're going to go around the circle, and everyone who chooses to share will share the personal need that they'd like to gift themselves and the movement that goes along with it. Here is a sentence that you might want to complete:

"I would like to give myself the gift of ______________."

"Right after you finish sharing your words, you can do a body movement that goes along with them. The rest of the group will repeat your words and movement together. Again, you can choose to share this way, or in any other way you'd like. If you just want to share your sentence, that's OK.

"Thank you for sharing and acknowledging that all of our needs. All of them are valid and very important! Did we notice any similarities in our needs? Any differences?

Note About Introducing Embodied Art
Consider sharing with the youth the benefits of moving their bodies in playful and safe ways. By sharing this information with them, you empower them to feel a sense of ownership over their bodies and their expression. For more about embodied art workshops and how to introduce them in your groups, see Introduction to Embodied Art Workshops.
Click here to see the Expressive Crayon Warm Up variation that includes additional emotions.

You can make this workshop quick and easy by using the Scratch Art Board flower shape!
For a list of other Scratch Art Board variations, click here.

Journaling/Warm up:
"First, pick a color that feels safe to you or speaks to you or simply use your journal. We are going to journal about 3 different types of needs we all have: the needs of our body, our mind and those of our spirit. As you can see th at I have done with this paper, please take a piece of paper (choose a color that makes you feel comfortable and safe or even strong and hopeful). Fold that paper into thirds lengthwise, like you would a letter. On the top of the first column, write the word Physical, on the second Emotional, and on the third Spiritual. If you are using your journal, you can instead draw two lines on the page to designate three separate sections.

I'm going to talk a little bit about each of these three needs and give you two minutes after each one to write and reflect on this need for yourself. Keep in mind that there is no right or wrong way to do this journaling exercise. You can write sentences, words, lists, draw symbols, shapes, or anything else you like. The most important thing is that you don't censor yourself! Just allow your thoughts to flow onto your paper without judgment. What you write does not have to make sense to anyone but you! While you are journaling, your only job is to not stop writing! You will write about your physical, emotional, and spiritual needs doe a total of ten minutes. (You might want to play soft background music during this journaling portion).

"Physical needs are what we usually think about first. What are your physical needs in order to be safe, happy and healthy? (For example: We need to be free from harm. We need shelter and a safe place to live. We need good nutrition: healthy food and clean water. We need exercise - keeping our bodies healthy and strong. We need rest, giving us energy to do what we need to do, like succeeding at work or going to school.) In the first column, begin writing words, sentences, symbols or shapes to represent your physical needs (allow two minutes for this).

"Another need that may be a little harder to think about, but just as important are our emotional needs. What are your emotional needs in order to feel safe, happy, and healthy? (Examples are: feeling understood, feeling accepted and heard.) Knowing that we are loved and appreciated also gives us the feeling of having emotional support. Relaxation, fun, and friendship help us to find emotional balance. Having boundaries, realistic expectations, and a positive attitude are other ways of supporting our emotional health. Now in the second column, begin journaling about your emotional needs (allow two minutes for this).

"Finally, we will address our spiritual needs. What does your spirit need to give you peace? Is it the ability to forgive, have patience or acceptance of others? Do you need quiet time to reflect, meditate, or pray? Do you need to do good deeds or help others feel uplifted? Do you need "me" time to care for your soul? In the third column write words, sentences, shapes, or symbols to reflect your spiritual needs (allow two minutes for this).

"Thank you for taking the time to reflect on (and honor) your own personal needs. Remember that you are worth it and representing your needs shows that they are, too!"
For a visual art workshop that covers similar themes, see Life Clocks - You Decide.
You can use this workshop as a way to set New Year's resolutions when creating the "ideal" image.

Description
In this embodied art workshop, participants get to explore their "typical" day and their ideal day nonverbally. In this "rehearsal for real life" process, they have the opportunity to better understand their experiences, needs, an d visions.

Materials
No materials needed except enough space to have a "sharing"/performance area and a "witness"/audience area.

Time Frame
Creating Safety with Embodied Art: 5 min.
Name and Gesture Warm-Up: 5-10 min. (depending on group size)
Image of the Hours: 40-60 min. (depending on group size)
Closing Circle: 10-15 min. (depending on group size)
Total: 1-1.5 hours (depending on group size)

 

Creating Safety with Embodied Art

 
 
 Participants take a window of time to connect
to their bodies in their own ways.

"Many of us have consciously or unconsciously disconnected from our bodies as a way to cope with trauma. When we use our bodies to explore our inner and outer worlds, we can start to reconnect to ourselves. This process can support us in feeling more whole and integrated. When we do this in community or in a group we may not only connect to ourselves more deeply but connecting to others. Sometimes, new things can feel anywhere from exhilarating to silly or uncomfortable. Throughout today's workshop, notice how you are feeling and only do what feels right for you and your body.

"Today, we're going to take a window of time to connect with each other and ourselves by doing some movement related to how we each want to spend our time. Throughout this workshop, we'll get an opportunity to connect to our playfulness and to our bodies in a safe and supportive way--this means you get to decide what safe and supportive means to you. For example, maybe you can't wait to move around or maybe you want to challenge yourself by trying something new. Maybe you want to connect and play by watching other people experiment or sitting quietly with a hand over your heart and just breathing deeply. Know that in this window of time, you get to decide what's right for you. I will make some invitations, and you get to honor yourself and your body in whatever way feels right to you.

"To begin, let's stand together in a circle."

 

Name and Gesture Warm-Up
Stand in a circle with participants. Invite each person to share how they are feeling today with their name and a movement (for example, by saying "sleepy Ana" while yawning and stretching or shouting "excited Bobby" while jumping up and down). After each person shares, the whole group repeats the feeling, name, and movement twice, trying to match the original person's words, tone, and movement as exactly as possible, while still taking care of their bodies. Remind participants that they can always pass and take care of their bodies. For example, if someone jumps really high but you have injured knees, you can do your own version of jumping-for example, maybe that looks like raising your shoulders instead or even just thinking about jumping instead of doing it. Click here to see a short video of this warm-up.

 

Image of the Hours

  1.   
      Sharers show what they do at 4 a.m.
    Introduction: Begin by giving a preview of the process: "In this next activity, we're going to get a chance to notice and share what a typical day looks like for us and later we'll get a chance to notice and share what our ideal day would be like. However, instead of just talking about it, we're going to show with movement what we do during the day without using words or sounds. Half the group will have the opportunity to share while the other half will witness and reflect back silently what they saw, and then we'll switch. At the very end, after we've each had a chance to share and witness, then we'll get a chance to share what that experience was like for us. As a reminder, this is your window of time, so you get to practice honoring your thoughts, feelings, needs, and bodies--that could mean that when acting out ‘sleeping' you lie down on the floor or you could just stand and close your eyes or you could choose to pause and get a drink of water, and so on. There's no right or wrong way to participate here."

  2. Divide the group in two: Have one group be the "sharers" and the other group be the "witnesses" first. Invite all the witnesses to sit together, facing the sharing area. Welcome the sharers to the sharing area.

  3.  
      Sharers show their 8 a.m. images to witnesses.
    Creating images: "I will be calling out hours of day, such as 1 p.m., 2 p.m., etc. At each hour the sharers will silently act out whatever it is that they usually do at that time everyday. If you don't have a typical day, you can pick something that you do frequently at that time or choose a specific day like yesterday. After we've gone through the whole 24 hour day, the witnesses will reflect back 3 images that they saw and remembered. Any questions?" After answering any questions that come up, invite the sharers to start in a position of what they are doing at 4 a.m. (for many people, this would be sleeping). Begin calling out the hours of the day, with long pauses between each hour to give participants a chance to show what they do. "4 a.m. ... 5 a.m. ... 6 a.m. ... 7 a.m. ... 8 a.m. ... 9 a.m. ... 10 a.m. ... 11 a.m. ... 12-noon ... 1 p.m. ... 2 p.m. ... 3 p.m. ... 4 p.m. ... 5 p.m. ... 6 p.m. ... 7 p.m. ... 8 p.m. ... 9 p.m. ... 10 p.m. ... 11 p.m. ... 12-midnight ... 1 a.m. ... 2 a.m. ... 3 a.m. ... and all the way back to 4 a.m. ... Witnesses, give a round of applause to the sharers for their courage and creativity!"

  4.   
      Witnesses reflect back images they saw.
    Reflection: "Now, sharers take a seat, and witnesses come up to the sharing area to reflect back some of the images that you saw. This is an opportunity to let the sharers know that they were seen and that their experiences are acknowledged. You'll get an opportunity to act out three of the different things you saw. Any questions?" After answering any questions, call out "Image 1" and pause for the witnesses to show one thing they saw. Then call out "Image 2" and pause again for the witness to show something else they saw. Finally, call out "Image 3" and pause for the witnesses to show a third thing they saw. Offer an opportunity for the original sharers to give appreciative applause for their witnesses.

  5. Switch roles: Repeat steps 3 and 4 with the groups in opposite roles (the sharers become the witnesses, and the witnesses become the sharers).

  6. Discussion: Invite the group to share what they noticed and if anything surprised them. Validate the feelings and experiences that came up for participants.

  7. Transition: Ask the group if the day they showed is how they'd like their day to be in their ideal world. If they say no (as most groups do), say to them, "So let's take a window of time to imagine how we would like our days to be-how we would set up our day if we didn't have to settle for anything less than absolutely everything. In order to give our visioning a little flexibility, this time, instead of calling out specific hours, I'll be calling out general times of the day, such as ‘early morning,' and witnesses will reflect back just two of the images."

  8.  
      Sharers show their ideal evening.
    Ideal images: Invite one group to come to the sharing area and start in a position of what they are ideally doing in the early morning. Begin calling out the times of the day, with long pauses between each hour to give participants a chance to show what they do. "Early morning ... late morning ... 12-noon ... afternoon ... evening ... late night ... 12-midnight ... and back to early morning ... Witnesses, give a round of applause to the sharers for sharing their visions!"

  9. Reflection: "Now, sharers take a seat and witness get ready to reflect back some of the images you just saw. Maybe you want to try out an image because you think it might be good for your ideal day or maybe it stands out to you for another reason. Ready?" Call out "Image 1" and pause for the witnesses to show one thing they saw. Then call out "Image 2" and pause again for the witness to show something else they saw. Finally, offer an opportunity for the original sharers to give appreciative applause for their witnesses.

  10. Switch roles: Repeat steps 8 and 9 with the groups in opposite roles (the sharers become the witnesses, and the witnesses become the sharers).

  11. Discussion: Invite the group to share what they noticed and if anything surprised them. Ask what was different about their typical day and their ideal day. Validate the feelings and experiences that came up for participants.


Closing Circle
If not everyone has had an opportunity to share, invite participants to go around and share one thing they appreciated about this workshop or themselves and any final word that they'd like to say. Remind participants that they have the option to pass.


 
 Participants hold hands in
the closing circle breaths.
 
  

Thank the participants for connecting to themselves, their experiences, and the expression of their bodies. Close out the group with collective breaths: "Now we are going to take three breaths together. This first breath is for this group right here." Pause to let everyone breathe together. "The second breath is for yourself." Pause to let everyone breathe together. "The third breath is for your ideal day and all the support you can get to make it a reality." Pause to let everyone breathe together.
For a visual art workshop that covers similar themes, see the My Time workshop.
You can use this workshop as a way to set New Year's resolutions when creating the "ideal" image.

Instead of ending the embodied exercise with a quote from Brené Brown, you could share this quote from Mia McKenzie, creator of Black Girl Dangerous and author of The Summer We Got Free, as another way to talk about letting go of protection in order to be fully ourselves and free:

“A long time ago, when you were a wee thing, you learned something, some way to cope, something that, if you did it, would help you survive. It wasn’t the healthiest thing, it wasn’t gonna get you free, but it was gonna keep you alive. You learned it, at five or six, and it worked, it *did* help you survive. You carried it with you all your life, used it whenever you needed it. It got you out–out of your assbackwards town, away from an abuser, out of range of your mother’s un-love. Or whatever. It worked for you. You’re still here now partly because of this thing that you learned. The thing is, though, at some point you stopped needing it. At some point, you got far enough away, surrounded yourself with people who love you. You survived. And because you survived, you now had a shot at more than just staying alive. You had a shot now at getting free. But that thing that you learned when you were five was not then and is not now designed to help you be free. It is designed only to help you survive. And, in fact, it keeps you from being free. You need to figure out what this thing is and work your ass off to un-learn it. Because the things we learn to do to survive at all costs are not the things that will help us get FREE. Getting free is a whole different journey altogether.”

http://www.blackgirldangerous.org/2013/02/2013219vyv1ekfq9ycl8uvz44kfhzyhjzgin5/
You can also begin to introduce the workshop with the concept of how "Eyes are the windows to our soul." This quote has had a big impact on some participants.
To contrast with the negative feelings falling off the fall tree, in the spring children could make a "springtime tree" on which positive feelings grow.

Completed Paper Han d Mandala
 
Materials:
Poster board or large piece of foam core
Glue dots
Easel, stand, or table to display the mandala

Pre-workshop Prep:
Make sure you have an easel, stand, or table to place the poster board or foam core on so that the mandala is highly visible to the participants. If possible, having the board or foam core in an upright position encourages participation since it allows people to see the beautiful creation unfold. Before the workshop begins, you may want to prepare a hand and attach it to the middle of the board. This will ensure the mandala is centered. Having pre-cut paper hands in multiple colors helps create a colorful and eye-catching mandala.

 
 
  The 3rd participant adds her I CAN hand
 
 
 
  Staff assists participant with adding a glue dot  
Creation:
After each person is done creating their I CAN hand, ask them if they'd like to have their photo taken in front of the mandala. We've found that people, especially youth, love having their photo taken. Because many people have camera phones, you can offer to take the picture with their phone so they leave with a tangible reminder of their creation.

Next, ask if they'd like to take their hand home or if they want to add it to the mandala. If they choose to add it to the mandala, attach a glue dot to the base of the palm or wrist of the hand (on the back of the paper they created on). This helps ensure that everyone attaches their hand in a uniform way, and also creates a visually pleasing and cohesive mandala.

Note: If you have enough supplies, you can encourage participants to make one for your board and one to take home.
  
 
  Participant adds her creation to the mandala

Objective: This workshop provides an opportunity for participants to take a 'window of time" to let go of burdens and connect to a sense of possibility and well being through mediation and the creative process.

Materials:
Natural stones of any size
Paint pens in assorted colors
Journals to decorate (and get the paint pens flowing)
Optional: If needed, you could substitute paint pens with permanent markers.

Time-frame:
Window of Time Introduction - 1 minute
Opening Circle - 5 minutes
Workshop Introduction - 2 minutes
Material Demo - 1 minute
Visualization/Creation - 10-15 minutes

Window of Time Introduction: This is your Window of time to practice respecting your thoughts, feelings, needs and visions. Think of it a special space to notice what you need to feel happy, healthy and whole. During your window of time there is no wrong way to create or express, so do only what feels good and safe for you.

Opening Circle:
Allow everyone share one or a few words about their unmet needs. You may say something like, "To start everyone will get to share any need you have in this moment. Anything that maybe throwing you off balance -physically, emotionally, spiritually, or intellectually can affect your health and well-being. In one or a few words, please share about an unmet need you may have in this moment

Workshop Introduction:
Thank you for taking this time for you, to  notice what you need to feel happy, healthy and whole. Sometime when we hear the word "wellness", it may feel out of reach especially when we think of it in terms of "having wellness" vs."not having wellness", being healthy or not being healthy. Like anything else we are creating, wellness is a process. When we think of it in this way we can start thinking of it as a wellness path. We can think of it, as not a destination or outcome, but the steps we can each make to take better care of ourselves. 

Today we are going to create stepping stones. One stepping stone will represent what you are ready or need to let go of, or leave behind,that is keeping you out of balance or off of your wellness path- - this could be a feeling, a thought or something more tangible. The other stone can represent a step or whatever you'll need to move forward on your wellness path.

Material Demo:
After I introduce the materials I will turn on some music and share a brief visualization and then will jump in to creating our stepping stones. So, our materials are are stones and paint pens - The only thing to know about the paint pens is that you may need to push down a bit to get the color flowing. Using the pens,  you can write a word or words, images, colors - whatever feels right for you in the moment. Any questions about the materials?

Visualization/Creation:
(Turn on some music) Ask folks to get comfortable in their seats and begin... take some deep cleansing breaths and let your eyes close if that feels okay… as you continue to breathe... imagine that you have come to a lovely path that feels safe and comfortable... as you continue on this path notice that you get to choose how you move throughout it...look around at the colors, feel the clean air,notice the space around you… as you make your way through, you notice a colorful stone that reminds you of what you most want and need... you notice this lovely path has brought you back to yourself and you are ready to let go of those ideas thoughts or feelings that are holding you back and that you get to choose where your journey takes you next.  notice how it feels in your body to have this awareness and take another deep breath in… and when your feel ready open your eyes and create your stepping stones.

Closing:
Have participants share anything about their stepping stones, with reminders that all sharing is voluntary.

Thank participants and remind them to take their stones as reminders of the journey to self-love, self-care and well being. Also, offer folks the opportunity, if they choose, to literally leave behind the stones that represent what they feel ready to let go of in the empty baskets, and that we will love and honor their burdens and lay them to rest.

If you have a only large pockets, participants can decorate pockets and string them across a doorway, in the art room, or anywhere within your shelter or outreach center. <br /><table border="0" align="center"><tbody><tr><td>&nbsp;</td><td><font color="#333366"><img xsrc="/awbw/u/workshops/DenimDayClothesline.jpg" border="1" alt=" " width="268" height="118" /></font> <br /></td><td>&nbsp;</td></tr><tr><td>&nbsp;</td><td class="TextCaption" align="center">&nbsp;Pockets hanging on a clothesline.<br /></td><td>&nbsp;</td></tr></tbody></table>

A promise on the inside
To shorten this workshop, have participants make only one pocket.

If you don't have access to t-shirts, you can easily do this workshop with paper t-shirts. Simply download the paper t-shirt template below, or create your own t-shirt templates and enjoy. Use string and small clothespins to create the same effect as the regular Clothesline Project workshop.
Paper T-shirt template

   
   
   
  Mini Clothesline Project with paper t-shirts!

Create mini versions of The Clothesline Project with Shrinky-Dink paper! Simply download the t-shirt template below. Participants can make keepsake necklaces and bracelets with ribbon and beads to wear and remind themselves of the statements they made. They'll make great conversation-starters!
Shrinky-Dink template

 
 
   
   
  Clothesline Project with Shrinky-Dink t-shirts!

The Resilience Stones workshop lend themselves to community engagement projects at a conference event, tabling sessions, and drop-in activities! You can use this tri-fold instructions as a centerpiece and talking piece on your table to invite participants to create their own stones.
     
  Resilience Stones instructions and materials at exhibit
  Resilience Stones instructions and materials at tabling event 

There are five simple steps to engage the community with the creation of these beautiful and empowering stones! Invite participants to:

1. Reflect —  What connects you to your strength? What helps you meet challenges? What gives you the ability to bounce back from set backs? What gives you hope? What inspires you?

2. Create — Draw an image, symbol, colors and/or words that came to you as you reflected upon your resilience.

3. Glue — Add ample glue to your creation.

4. Add Glass Stone­ —­ Place glass stone on top of your creation and press down firmly.

5. Finish — Wipe off excess glue.

 
       

We recommend that participants Create up to 3 Resilience Stones to help remind them of their strength and power and to keep with them.

The Resilience Stones workshop lend themselves to community engagement projects at a conference event, tabling sessions, and drop-in activities! You can use this tri-fold instructions as a centerpiece and talking piece on your table to invite participants to create their own stones.
     
  Resilience Stones instructions and materials at exhibit
  Resilience Stones instructions and materials at tabling event 

There are five simple steps to engage the community with the creation of these beautiful and empowering stones! Invite participants to:

1. Reflect —  What connects you to your strength? What helps you meet challenges? What gives you the ability to bounce back from set backs? What gives you hope? What inspires you?

2. Create — Draw an image, symbol, colors and/or words that came to you as you reflected upon your resilience.

3. Glue — Add ample glue to your creation.

4. Add Glass Stone­ —­ Place glass stone on top of your creation and press down firmly.

5. Finish — Wipe off excess glue.

 
       

We recommend that participants Create up to 3 Resilience Stones to help remind them of their strength and power and to keep with them.

Using small 1/2 inch stones you can make multiples!  Ideal for carrying personal messages that support your intentions. The small stones are perfect to add words or symbols.

 
     
 Create many small stones
  Send a message or intention
  Carry them with you
 as a reminder
 

Colored ball point pens or super fine Sharpies work best on the small stones. You can use a 1/2 inch hole punch to create the circles.

This is recommended for children aged 12 + the small stones could be a choking hazard, plan accordingly

With the the image showing on one side, feel free to add words, symbols or a special date on the "back" side. This can provide a personal reminder, message or affirmation for yourself or others.

   
  Send an extra message by writing on the back.

Give One, Take One (inspired by give a penny, take a penny)

Just as stores have dishes with pennies for people to "give a penny, take a penny" you can create a "Give a Touchstone, Take a Touchstone" area at your agency and encourage anyone who comes to your agency to select a Touchstone to take home and if they like, create a Touchstone to add to the dish.  Simply select an area (at AWBW we put the supplies on top of a bookshelf) and put all of the workshop supplies in bowls or baskets so they are easily accessible. 

 
 
  Touchstone Make One,Take One display of supplies
 

Whenever someone who does not know about the Touchstones project comes into the agency, share about the project, walk them over to the area and ask them if they'd like to select a Touchstone.  Welcome them to either take the first one they touch or look though until they find the Touchstone that most resonates with them.  After they have selected their stone, encourage them to use their Touchstone as a tangible connection to others.
If time permits, invite them to create a Touchstone to leave behind for another person to take.  Be sure to share briefly about the "window of time" and how there is no right or wrong way to do art to help support their creative process.    

   
  Bowl to leave a stone to take a stone
 
You can also facilitate this as a group activity by having each person create two Touchstones, one for themselves and one to leave behind.  At the end of the group have everyone share about their stones and then add the Touchstone they created to leave behind to a basket or bowl.  You can also welcome the participants to take a Touchstone from the communal bowl.

Objetivo:
Explorar y conocer la persona que dejas que los demás conozcan, y la persona que llevas dentro o debajo.

Materiales:
9”X12” papel de color
Pasteles de tiza
Toalla de papel
Plumas y papel para escribir
(Opción: mujeres pueden utilizar sus agendas)
Hoja informativa (para taller individual)
Variaciones alternativas:  Este taller puede utilizar collage envés de pasteles.  Utilizando collage se puede utilizar cajas o bolsas en vez de papel de color.

Tiempo:
Tiempo total:  1 hora
Intro: 5 minutos
Circulo de abertura:  10 minutos
Escribir en Agenda:  10 minutos
Creación:  30 minutos
Circulo de clausura:  10 minutos

Organizar:
Ayuda bastante cuando los materiales están preparados antes del taller.  Intenta varias maneras de doblar el papel, para mostrar a las mujeres.  Usa los pastels para hacer un ejemplo. Podrás notar si hay material que hace falta.

Introducción:
“Este tiempo es especial es ‘una ventana en tiempo’ para cada una de ustedes.  El taller que vamos hacer se llama Dentro/Fuera.  Es una oportunidad para explorar el “tu” que la gente ve afuera y el “tu” que solo tu conoces por dentro.  Vamos a utilizar papel doblado y pastels para crear el afuera y adentro que tenemos, usando diferentes formas y colores.  

Circulo de abertura:
Toma el tiempo para dar la bienvenida a todos, dejándole saber que son apreciados.  “Antes de empezar el arte,  vamos a tener un circulo para compartir nuestros nombres, como se sienten hoy, y sus sentimientos hacia el arte.”  Es buen tiempo para asegurar les que esta bien si tienen miedo y esta bien si lo “odian.”  Recuérdales que no tienen que hacer el taller.  Pueden observar si no quieren participar.  Dando la libertad para participar motiva a la gente que solo piensa observar.  Si no quieren compartir, deja les saber que esta bien.

Agenda Calentamiento:
“Vamos ha empezar escribiendo en nuestras agendas.  Dividan una hoja de papel en dos.  De un lado escriban “Adentro” del otro lado escriban “Afuera.”  Llenen el lado que dice adentro con palabras que describen como se sienten adentro al otro lado escriban palabras que describan lo que la gente ve afuera.  Traten de no pensar tanto cuando escriben.  Permitan que las palabras salgan naturalmente.  Si no pueden pensar en más palabras vallan a la próxima columna y regresen a la primera después.  Después de que terminen tomen un momento para observar las palabras que han escrito sin juzgar.  Simplemente reconózcanlas y acéptenlas como parte de ustedes.  Las palabras servirán como guía durante su creación.”

Creación:
“Ahora escoge una pieza de papel y dobla la para que tenga un porción adentro y una afuera.  Empieza a crear la parte de afuera mientras que piensas en colores, texturas, y formas, cosas que te describen por fuera.  Siempre puedes leer las cosas que has escrito en tu papel.  Eres brillante, oscura, fuerte, o clara?

Cuando estés lista abre tu papel y piensa como eres por dentro.  Eres brillante, oscura, suave o dura?  Eres varios colores o uno?  Usa los pastels o collaging para decorar la parte de adentre y de afuera de tu papel.

Cuando termines toma unos minutos para anotar unas palabras que vallan con tu creación.  (Puedes tomar un minuto para animar a las mujeres en pensar de diferentes maneras que se pueden cuidar por dentro y por fuera)

Circulo de Clausura:
Da a cada mujer una oportunidad para compartir lo que ha creado, lo que quiere decir y lo que siente.  Valida el valor que tuvieron en abrirse con su propia creatividad y por respetar lo que salio.

This self-led version of Inside/Outside can be perfect for older children/teens who aren't quite comfortable with the group setting. You can supply them with the proper materials and this form and set a check-in time to discuss their experience as well.

Click here to download the form.

This daily practice and affirmation can serve as an affirmation or intention on a regular basis - daily, weekly, monthly, or each time your Windows group meets!

After building a repertoire of Touchstones that are meaningful to them, participants can choose one from their collection and use the message as one to focus on. This exercise can promote a healthy and positive mantra, mindfulness, and groundedness.

You may want to use this workshop to engage the children/youth or families in a dialogue about the many different types of families. We recommend using books that support a dialogue that is inclusive of all different types of families. Some of our favorites include: What is a Family by Eton B oritzer, And Tango Makes Three by Justin Richardson and Peter Parnell or The Family Book by Todd Parr.

Holiday Feelings Dance Warm-up:
“Sometimes, during the holiday season, we feel lots of different feelings.  Our parents sometimes do too.  Have you noticed that?  What feelings have you noticed inside of you during the holidays?  What feelings have you noticed around you during the holidays?   Have you ever seen people rushing, in a big hurry?  Have you seen people sad and lonely?  Have you seen people happy and singing?  What have you seen?”  (Encourage a sharing of thoughts and then have all the children stand in a circle for the Holiday Feelings Dance.  Begin to move around, like when we do the Monster Dance.)  “Now let’s make up a Holiday Feelings Dance together.  We can start by moving around in a circle together, slowly at first, and now faster and faster.  Can you become a rushing holiday person?  And now can you be a happy holiday person?  How about a silly holiday person?  And now, a sad holiday person?  And can you be a peaceful, relaxed holiday person?  So peaceful, so relaxed...  Let’s go slower and slower, peaceful and more peaceful, and find our way back to our seats to relax!  Beautiful!”   

For older kids:  Instead of a dance, have a circle of sharing thoughts out loud.  Ask each person to share the good and bad feelings they’ve noticed inside them and around them during the holiday season.  Whoever doesn’t want to share any thoughts can pass.

Materials:
 
 
    Twist into a "snake" using 3 colors
  
  
  
   Roll into a ball and Flatten Sculpey into a rock shape
Super Sculpey Polymer Clay
Toaster Oven
Sharpie markers (metallic Sharpies work best)

Preparation:
Prepare the Sculpey Clay by breaking up the blocks into in various colored balls of clay. Make sure to have enough clay for each person to make two stones.  If you only have a short amount of time to do the workshop, use real rocks or pre-baked Sculpey rocks.

As you guide the relaxation and painting process, you could focus on words that bring hope.  For example strength, wisdom, courage, joy. The participants could imagine breathing these things in, feeling them fill their bodies, and express them in shapes and colors in their paintings.

As you guide the relaxation and painting process, you could imagine breathing in self-care, listening deeply for what we need to do to take care of ourselves, and noticing whatever shapes and colors come to mind as we think of taking care of ourselves.

With this variation, you could encourage the participants to notice a worry or challenge that they want guidance or help with and put it into shapes and colors. Then, through the process
of painting that shape in consecutive paintings, the participants can see what emerges and how it transforms, just in shapes and colors, exploring how that challenge can be resolved or transformed.

Have a jar of inspirational quotes so each participant can pick one without looking, see what the quote inspires in them, and then paint shapes and colors inspired by the quote (see enclosed list to copy and cut up for your jar).
Or:
Hand out the entire list of inspirational quotes for each participant to read. Invite them to choose their favorite ones and then create paintings expressing these quotes in shapes and
colors.

Row.str_name: Binding into a Painted Prayers Book
Row.txt_code: The paintings and words from any of these variations could be bound together into little books each participant can use as a source of inspiration and strength. It could be a Personal Reminders Book, a Personal Rulebook, a Personal Inspiration Book. Each participant can come up with their own titles and purpose for how they want to use their book.
